name: All for One and One for All
Beat Your Neighbour Out of Doors
Deuces & Jacks & the Man with the Axe
Five Card Draw with a Bug
Five Card Stud High-Low With a Buy
Good, the Bad and the Ugly, The
Seven Card Stud with Wild Cards
Tarot of the Abbé de Marolles
Want it? Want it? Got it!
5 Card Stud High-Low With a Buy
Aardvark Game
notes: A game for friends, created by James Quin, Adam Tilghman, Luke Weisman and Renée Sharp.

name: Abracadabra
notes: A trick-taking game with exact bidding by Paul Newton, in which players not only predict how many tricks they will win, but also which ones.

name: Abroasta
notes: A speed game by Tom Acker and Rachel Secenghier, reminiscent of Spit or Racing Demon but much simpler.

name: Abstrac
notes: A game of perfect information for two players, by David Parlett. The 24 cards are laid out face up in a row and players take turns to remove cards from one end, trying to collect combinations.

name: Abundance
notes: A two-player game by Matthew Shields, in which cards are auctioned, and the suits that turn out to be most abundant have the least value.

name: Accelerated Phase 10
notes: A streamlined Phase 10 variant by Derek and Clark Rodeffer in which on completing a Phase the player immediately discards the cards used, draws replacements and continues playing for the next phase.

name: Ace Chasing
notes: A game by Matthew Allen in which players swap single cards and bet on whether the final player will have the lowest card.

name: Ace of Death
notes: A simple but violent game, related to Ace of Spades and Suicide, contributed by Patrick Nance.

name: Ace of Spades
notes: A game of impressive simplicity, explained by Eric J. Egolf.

name: Ace Pit
notes: An unusual two-player trick-taking game, contributed by Bill Hurn.

name: Ace Race
notes: A card game for 2, 3, 4 or 6 players by Adam Mepham and Samantha Le, in which the object is to get rid of cards, and the player of an ace can change the rule of play.

name: Aces and Faces Quarto
notes: An adaptation by Eugene Fitzgerald of the board game Quarto, using a standard deck of cards.

name: Addenda
notes: An adding up and trick-taking game for two or four players, by David Parlett. Each trick consists of four cards, one of each suit, and is won by the last player who keeps the total value of the cards played to 17 or less.

name: Adder
notes: A game by Steven Hammon in which players try to get rid of their cards by discarding them on three piles.

name: Addition War
notes: A War variation by Jesse Weinstein and Nancy Fuller in which cards are played two at a time and added.

name: Advanced Switch
notes: A variation of Switch (British equivalent of Crazy Eights), contributed by David Walters.

name: Advantage
notes: An unusual two-player game by J. Brukhman, in which players try to form pairs by a process of playing cards to a layout, exchanging hands, and exchanging cards from their hands with piles from the layout.

name: Aggravation
notes: A Contract Rummy variation from Bette Procter.

name: Alamo
notes: A game by Nathaniel Meadow based on the structure of Texas Holdem Poker but with cards used for betting as well as for making hands, the object being to win cards to add to your deck as in War.

name: Ambition
notes: A four-player point-trick game by Mike Church, in which twos are high if an ace or picture card of the same suit is played, but low otherwise, and the aim is to take the second highest number of points in each deal.

name: Ambusch
notes: A Rummy-like game by Jack Russell and Steven Ellis, in which the winner of each hand saves the final discard to try to build a winning poker hand over a series of deals.

name: American Bank
notes: A competitive patience game by Bill Perkins

name: Anandis
notes: A game in which the two players try to guess the identity of a face-down card, gathering evidence by forcing the opponent to reveal cards of a particular number and suit.

name: Anarchy
notes: A game of the eights type, but with stronger than usual restrictions on what cards can be played, by Jimmy Kaplowitz and Kofi Mills.

name: Android Whist
notes: A two player card game by Tuomas Korppi in which each human player is partnered with a robot player that responds to a limited set of commands.

name: Angel
notes: A draw and discard game by Rick Orobko, in which a player can call for "judgement" when they think they have the best hand.

name: Ants
notes: A two-player game by Brad Paras in which the object is to complete an ant colony of 14 cards - ace to ace - in your colour.

name: Arlington
notes: This has nothing to do with the Rummy game of the same name. It is a game for two to six players which involves getting, playing, and keeping played certain combinations of cards. It was contributed by Dennis Himes.

name: Army
notes: A straightforward game of turning over cards, somewhat like War, except that instead of collecting won cards a score is kept on paper. Contributed by by Justin Kohli.

name: Army
notes: A simple two-player game by Kia Green in which cards are played simultaneously and the loser of each round loses a stamina point.

name: Army Ants
notes: A two-player game by Bryan Winter, essentally a board game between red and black using 19 playing-cards each as pieces, the aim being to capture the enemy Queen.

name: Ascending Rules Uno
notes: An Uno variation, contributed by Chris O'Hare.

name: Ascension
notes: A cooperative combat game using standard playing-cards. Two players help each other to survive against a deck of monsters. The inventor Tony Ngo has provided a video introduction on youtube.

name: Ascot
notes: One of Keith Stevens' new card games. The aces take part in a 'horse race' controlled by the tricks taken in a game of German Whist.

name: Assassin
notes: A poker variation by Joel Lau.

name: Assassin Ace
notes: A variation of Suicide (in which players are eliminated if they turn over the Ace of Spades), by Jason Krueger.

name: Attack
notes: A War variation by Michael Camarata in which players have five-card hands to play from.

name: Attackjack
notes: A Blackjack-based game by Caedyn Danow, in which the players play against each other rather than individually against the bank.

name: Auction
notes: A game for 2 or more players by Alex Kutsenok in which players use numeral cards from their hands to bid for picture cards turned up from the deck.

name: Auction Flop Poker
notes: A kind of Draw Poker in which players pay to discard and bid for replacement cards, by Charles Magri.

name: Auction Scumbag
notes: A President variation with auctioning of cards, contributed by Nathan Hedt.

name: Autumn Leaves
notes: A straightforward but challenging solitaire game with similarities to Spider, by Toby Ord.

name: Avalanche
notes: An original game for 2 to 6 players by Légrády Gábor and Kápolnás György.

name: Awol Bridge
notes: A three-handed bridge variant by Martin Chapman.

name: Babar
notes: A card game by Kevin Langouët related to 4-card Golf in which players exchange cards directly with each other rather than drawing and discarding.

name: Babies' Daddy
notes: A 7-card Stud variant by Bill Curran.

name: Backwards Cribbage
notes: A Cribbage variation by Cody Myers-Miller in which the object is to avoid scoring points.

name: Bahama Taxi
notes: A board and card game Bartosz Sułkowski in which the 52 cards of the pack represent passenger pick-up points and destinations, and the board is a map on which players move their taxis, scoring points by delivering passengers to their destinations.

name: Barbecue
notes: This game for 3 to 7 players by Xavier Lardy uses special cards depicting sausages and kebabs which are rotated as they cook. The card designs and rules in many languages can be downloaded free from the web site.

name: Barbette
notes: A shortened version of Barbu requiring only 16 deals, by Warren Chang.

name: Barbu Bridge
notes: A hybrid of Barbu and Bridge invented by Mark Brader.

name: Barbu for 3 players
notes: Four three-player versions of the classic game Barbu, contributed by Noel Leaver, Don Lagosz-Sinclair, Mark Brader and David Smith.

name: Bargain Bin
notes: A simple card game by Kewlio in which playing a card increases or decreases one's own or another player's score.

name: Barra-Can
notes: An elaborate game of melding combinations with four discard piles, contributed by Carlos De La Riva.

name: Barry's and Les's
notes: A variation of President played with a pack in which each of the four suits is a different colour, by Anthony O'Dea and others.

name: Baseball, National League Rules
notes: A seven card stud poker variant by John Noriega.

name: Baseborn
notes: A game by Nick Bos in which player try to collect a flush by bidding for cards.

name: Bastard
notes: A shedding game contributed by Daniel Manship, in which the cards played must be of alternate colours.

name: Batallion
notes: A game for 3 to 6 players by Tim Orcutt, in which players attack and defend using sets of cards of the same suit.

name: Battle Ace
notes: An abstract board wargame by Gareth Mottram, played with cards which move, stack and attack with the aim of capturing the  enemy king or breaching the enemy stronghold.

name: Battle Pairs
notes: A straightforward game by William Malloy in which players race to make pairs from cards in their hands.

name: Battle Whist
notes: A four-player game by Jay.I Sharn - players try to collect high cards by drawing and discarding; then two players conduct a battle in which the higher cards win.

name: Battlefield Cribbage
notes: An interesting Cribbage variation by Shane Murphy, which incorporates a draw and discard mechanism similar to Golf. Played cards are placed in the "frontline" and are no longer part of a player's hand. At the start of each turn a card is drawn from the deck, or the card played to the frontline by the previous player is taken, to be replaced by a different played card.

name: Best, Pair and Thirty-One
notes: A hybrid for two players of several 17th and 18th century betting games, by Robert Reid.

name: Betrayal
notes: One player, unknown to the others, is the traitor; the others are allies. The traitor and allies try to eliminate each other by a series of 'accusations'. Contributed by glitchninja.

name: Beyond
notes: A sophisticated exact bidding game with a Bridge-like auction, contributed by Jens Bai.

name: Bid
notes: A GOPS variation by Brendan Winter.

name: Bid Fair
notes: A point trick game by Matthew Shields in which the contract is determined by a card chosen by each player from their hand.

name: Big Al's Guillotine
notes: A poker variation, contributed by Al.

name: Big Game, The
notes: A variation of Texas 42 played with an 8-8 set of dominoes, by Howard Fosdick.

name: Big Green Cucumber
notes: A quicker variant of the card game Cucumber, contributed by Robert Rutherford.

name: Bino
notes: "The Computer Math Card Game". Players race to make a high score using the cards of their hand to represent decimal and binary numbers. Contributed by Jim MacMath

name: Bird Dog
notes: A trick-taking game for three or two players by Nathaniel Meadow, in which the object is to collect pairs of Kings, Queens or Jacks.

name: Birthday Suit Uno
notes: Uno played with exposed cards.

name: Bisko-Bobo
notes: A somewhat intricate showdown game by Richard and Robert Peluso in which players try to form sets of cards of the same suit.

name: Bitch
notes: A crazy eights variation by Miles Dansereau.

name: Black Heart Rum
notes: Guide to an elaborate Rummy variation by Toby Vaughn.

name: Black Hole Cribbage
notes: A Cribbage variation contributed by Jesse Chrisman

name: Black Mariah
notes: This game by Ren Petrone is related to the traditional British game of Black Maria, with penalty scores for the ace, king and queen of spades. The differences are that in this game hearts are trumps, not penalty cards, and there is a positive score for winning tricks.

name: Black Rat
notes: A wagering game by Alan Kross-Vinson in which players try to collect cards worth as near as possible to 21 or 33 without going over these totals.

name: Blackbird
notes: A rummy-like game by Mal Jones, in which the type of cards that can be melded is controlled by the top card of a second discard pile (the "trick pile").

name: Blackout with Jokers
notes: A variant of Oh Hell! with two Jokers. The first played is nominated as the highest or lowest card and the second then takes on the opposite value. Contributed by Dick Atkinson.

name: Blackwidowstar
notes: A game for one player by Joseph Smith, in which the player tries to guess the order of cards in a shuffled deck.

name: Blades of Steel
notes: A two-player hockey game with cards designed by Craig Bednar.

name: Blast
notes: A Shithead variation by Kyle St Hilaire. Each card played must be equal to or lower than the last (aces low). Twos have no special power. Tens clear the pile, as do three or more cards of the same rank played consecutively.

name: Blind
notes: A game of card matching, which "can last 5 seconds or 5 hours, depending on your luck". Contributed by Justin Swartsel.

name: Blind Hold'em
notes: A rapid fixed stake poker game by Ilya Bugreyev.

name: Blind Man's Switch
notes: Players switch cards, aiming to obtain the highest card. Contributed by Lee Perry.

name: Blind Omaha
notes: A rapid fixed stake poker game by Ilya Bugreyev.

name: Blindsided
notes: A simple draw and discard card game by Sally Webb in which players try to collect high cards.

name: Blue Beacon
notes: A poker variant contributed by Daniel J. Brooker

name: Boardwalk
notes: A new family of Solitaire games by Mark G. Meyers in which cards are accumulated by rank rather than by suit. With the free Java program provided you can play these games and customise the deck size and layout.

name: Bob Smith
notes: In this game, also known as 'Aiee', players are dealt five cards and select the highest valued combination of three, according to an elaborate counting system. Jokers have special effects of invalidating other hands, or can themselves be eliminated.

name: Boise
notes: A shared card poker variant by Douglas Wall.

name: Bombs Away
notes: A game for 2-5 players by Aviad Shani in which each card has a special effect.

name: Bong
notes: A fast and active shedding game for three or more players, invented by James Hayes and contributed by Scott Anthony.

name: Bonus Round
notes: An alternative to Dealer's Choice Poker, contributed by Jason Krueger.

name: Bottom Line Baccarat
notes: Baccarat variation by Jeff Cross in which red cards count as negative.

name: Bottom Line Blackjack
notes: Variation by Jeff Cross in which red cards count as negative.

name: Bounce Back
notes: A 5-card draw poker variant by George Weissenberger in which players can reclaim their discards.

name: Bowling Solitaire
notes: A simulation of 10-pin bowling using 20 cards from a standard 52-card pack, invented by Sid Sackson and published in his Gamut of Games.

name: Bowling Solitaire
notes: A card simulation of 10-pin bowling by Kimberly Mullen, much simpler than Sid Sackson's version.

name: Box
notes: A game by Richard Bradley in which each card played must be lower than or equal to the previous card.

name: Box
notes: A shared card poker variant by Bob Procter.

name: Bread and Chocolate
notes: A matching game for two players, in which each card played may enable the player to draw or discard some cards. The object is to run out of cards exactly. Invented by JC Ravage, Jimmy Kaplowitz, and Marc Jaffee.

name: Breaker
notes: A Texas Holdem Poker variant by George Weissenberger in which a joker can be used to destroy your opponent's straight or flush.

name: Brickards
notes: A variation by Bill Perkins of his card game Squaressi in which players simultaneously play a game of dominoes, the dominoes controlling the number of cards drawn from the stock.

name: Bridge with Deuces Wild
notes: A Bridge variant by Jeff Rubens.

name: Broadway
notes: A two-dimensional domino game for four players by Clark D. Rodeffer, in which points are scored for matching adjacent dominoes.

name: Brocky
notes: A Cuckoo variation by Mark Rinaldi in which all players involved in ties are dealt new cards which they can exchange again.

name: Broken Ladder
notes: An arithmetical draw and discard game by Logan Flinke.

name: Brucie's Play Your Cards Right Tennis
notes: A tennis format version of the Higher or Lower game popularised on British TV, contributed by Tom Hawkey, with a variant by Dominik Lubinski.

name: Buck Thirty-Five
notes: A variation of five-card draw poker for 4-6 players by Alfred Carter.

name: Buddys Game
notes: A poker variation contributed by Bob and Robin Procter.

name: Bugami
notes: A game by David Parlett, something like Hearts, except that before the play begins, each player independently chooses which suit to avoid.

name: Buh
notes: Buh is a betting and vying game, invented by Erik Max Francis. Hands consist of four cards and there is poker-like betting after the second, third and fourth cards are dealt. Hands are valued according to the pips of the cards they contain, but several cards of the same rank count as only one card, a sequence of cards counts as only the card with the highest value, and flushes halve the value of the hand.

name: Build Up
notes: A domino game designed by David Vander Ark in which stacks are built, and the aim is to have your own domino on top of the stack.

name: Bull Fight
notes: A variation of Bullshit using suits instead of ranks, contributed by Jake Cunninghame.

name: By the Skin of Your Teeth
notes: This game by Robert M Cook is also known as  Joker's Revenge. Players attack each other's defensive piles using combinations similar to Big Two.

name: Byzantium
notes: A game by Toby Ord for 1, 2, 3 or 4 players in which cards must be fitted into a tree layout in ascending or descending order.

name: Caged Rat
notes: A two-player game by Matthew Shields in which both try to capture the right number of cards to satisfy their two rats.

name: Cal's BS
notes: A variation of I Doubt It by Calvin Yoshitake.

name: Call Deuces
notes: A game for four or five players by Simon Haddad, in which the aim is to win tricks containing fives, and the bidder's partner is the holder of the deuce of trumps.

name: Canadian Salad Variations
notes: Variants of the compendium game Canadian Salad incuding an extended version contributed by "kermitfrog".

name: Candidate
notes: A two-player game by Matthew Shields in which players use faction cards to bid for candidate cards, and try to assemble scoring groups of candidates.

name: Canton
notes: A fishing game with dominoes invented by Fredrick Berndt, in which a played tile can capture one or two tiles from the end(s) of the layout if the pip total is right.

name: Captain Jack
notes: A ship combat game by Alan Barrett.

name: Capture
notes: An unusual two-player game by Jim DuBois, in which a card column captures an opposing column by containing the highest and lowest cards or a pair.

name: Capture the Commander
notes: A game of battles by Danny and Isabella Bruggeling in  which each player begins with a 13-card layout.

name: Caravan
notes: Adaptations by Kyle Mifflin and Joe Foxon of the two-player card game Caravan from the video game Fallout, in which players compete to form caravans of cards worth from 21 to 26 points.

name: Carbondale
notes: A card game by Ben Klemens for two to four players each of whom builds a grid of cards representing a town.

name: Card Explosion
notes: A round game by Nic Giacchino in which each card played must be no more than one different from the previous card, and there are bombs which cause the next player to pick up the play pile if they explode before being defused.

name: Card Triathlon
notes: A three-part game by Bill Oliver - the three legs have elements of Bridge, Canasta and Poker, and cards from each leg are kept for the next.

name: Cardigan
notes: A complicated trick-taking game in four deals, by Jared McComb.

name: CardOpoly
notes: Although this game by Mark Brown was inspired by Monopoly®, it is played with standard cards, and the mechanism is similar to that of Rummy.

name: CardRPG
notes: A role-playing game using standard playing-cards, by Ray of Ash. Stephen Rogers has contributed an advanced version of CardRPG, with extra powers and abilities and greater scope for strategy.

name: CardSen$e
notes: A game closely related to Barbu, but with fewer contracts and different scoring, contributed by Carolyn Bryan.

name: Cartiles
notes: A variation by Bill Perkins of his card game Squaressi in which players simultaneously play a game of dominoes, the dominoes controlling the number of cards drawn from the stock.

name: Castle Rock
notes: A domino game in which tiles are captured from the row when sandwiched between two tiles of the same suit.

name: Castle Wars
notes: A combat game for 2 players by Ryan Falzon.

name: Casualty War
notes: A War variation by Jesse Weinstein and Nancy Fuller in which cards are played three at a time.

name: Cat's Cradle
notes: An original solitaire game by Michael Bourne.

name: Cattura
notes: A game for 2-4 players using 32 cards, contributed by Cilibiu Dragos, in which players capture the top card of the central 'battle pile' by playing one or two cards of equal total value.

name: Challenge
notes: A domino game of bluff in which players claim to match a throw of two dice using tiles from their hand.

name: Chamberlain
notes: A cross between American Bid Whist and Polignac / Knaves, by Jonathan Ling.

name: Chameleon
notes: A trick taking game with bidding for three players, by Francis Dobbs.

name: Chameleon
notes: A poker variant by Paul DeLuca and Fritz Stei.

name: Checks
notes: A two-player game by James Yates in which players use groups of cards to capture single cards matching them in point value.

name: Chicks Rule
notes: A game with with the 78-card tarot pack in which any suit can be trumps. There is Bridge-like bidding to detrmine the trump suit and the minimum number of tricks that must be taken by the team that wins the bidding. Contributed by Mark Krebs.

name: Chimera
notes: A trick and trump game for 4 to 6 players by Francis Dobbs, with different values for each suit, and with bidding variants including a 2-player double dummy game.

name: Chinkway
notes: A five-player trick taking game with changing partners. The object of the game is to take tricks that include elements of a ‘Quest’ that changes for each deal. Contributed by Derek Carver.

name: Chit Chat
notes: A card game for two players that simulates the exchange of small talk between two acquaintances at a social function, contributed by Richard Vickery.

name: Chowaha
notes: Scot Wolfington's description of Mike Chow's shared card poker variant.

name: Chris-Cross Pairs
notes: A solitaire game of casting out pairs from a 25-card tableau, by Victor Wakefield.

name: Chug of War
notes: A drinking game by Clint Chaney.

name: Chukchi Sea Uno
notes: An Uno variation contributed by Shane Traceski.

name: Cincinnati Club Special
notes: A non-game, contributed by Keith Stewart, in which the objective is to fool the spectators.

name: Ciq
notes: An abstract combat game for 2 or more players by Jason Reed.

name: Circle Jerk
notes: A shared card poker variant by Tim Bates.

name: Circle of Power
notes: A card game about 4 warring emperors for 2 - 4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection.

name: Clan
notes: A point-trick game invented by Glenn Overby, described in late 16th century Scots.

name: Clash
notes: A kind of partition game for two players by Mike Church, in which each player forms 4-card, 3-card, 2-card and 1-card sets from a hand of 13 or 16 cards.

name: Climb the Ladder
notes: A partnership game by Scott Dieter, in which cards are discarded to a discard pile in ascending or descending sequence, the aim is to get rid of all your cards. The game begins with a kind of bidding process to choose the start card.

name: Clockwork Spades
notes: An automatic game for two players by Jamie Masculine, in which cards are played to a clockface formed from the spade suit.

name: Clogs
notes: A trick-taking game with some unusual features, created by Paul Weekes and Blake Vernon

name: Clone War
notes: A War variation by Ken Scherer

name: Clubbed
notes: A two-player card game invented by Dave Cline and his daughter Kendall in which players try to force cards on their opponent by playing clubs.

name: Clubs
notes: Nothing to do with the suit clubs, but a trick-taking game in which you add the cards you win in tricks to your hand, where your aim is to form pairs, threes and fours of a kind (known as clubs). Contributed by Drew Brokke.

name: Clubs
notes: A game based on Hearts with a few elements of Spades, in which Clubs are trump. Contributed by Daniel Clements.

name: Clubs
notes: An Oh Hell variation with a constant number of cards dealt and clubs as permanent trumps, created by Michael Lamar.

name: Clubs
notes: A three-player American trick-taking game in which clubs are permanent trumps, posted to rec.games.playing-cards by TC.

name: Clubs
notes: A point-trick game for four players with clubs as permanent trumps, created by Mitch Henke, Robert Ranz, Max Kromm, and Adam Bernstein.

name: Clubs
notes: A  point-trick game for 3 to 5 players by Zach Orlando, in which the lowest card wins the trick, and a single club in a trick reduces its value.

name: Clumond
notes: A game by Charles Magri, based on David Parlett's Ninety-Nine, but where the 'bid' is determined by the cards remaining at the end of the play, rather than being chosen in advance.

name: Code 9 Attack
notes: A card game of perfect information by José Adrião in which the object is to remove all nine cards of your suit from the grid.

name: Cold Omaha
notes: An Omaha Poker variant by Brett Johnson in which the community cards are dealt from players' discards.

name: Collecting Dominoes
notes: A children's domino game by Reiner Müller in which the aim is to collect tiles of one suit while avoiding other suits.

name: Collector
notes: A draw and discard game for 2-4 players by Tyler McCarn in which players try to collect a set of 13 cards, one of each rank.

name: Collusion
notes: A game of varying partnerships for four players, by David Parlett. Players collude to win the same number of tricks as exactly one other player.

name: Color Elevator
notes: A shedding game for 2-4 players by Aviad Shani, in which players get rid of cards onto two play piles.

name: Color Game
notes: A simple game in which players take turns to guess whether the next card of the deck will be red or black.

name: Color Gin
notes: A Gin Rummy variant by Sid Sackson in which scores contribute to four games played at once, one for each suit.

name: Colosseum
notes: A combat game inspired by Pokémon but played with standard cards, contributed by Enrique Santos.

name: Compass of Fate
notes: A game by Robert Kalin based on a much simplified version of Mah Jong. His web site includes designs for special cards for playing this game.

name: Conspiracy
notes: A partnership trick-taking game by Vinay Kolhatkar in which one partnership can look at each other's cards and discuss strategy before calling trumps and announcing how many tricks they will win.

name: Contemplation Crib
notes: A cribbage variant with some extra scores, by Rolanda Keene.

name: Cookie Monster
notes: A game by James Banks, in which the aim is to be the first to have your monster "eat" a row of cards in front of you, representing cookies.

name: Coosner
notes: A bidding type game by Jim Risner and John Cooper, in which cards are auctioned, and the bids in the auction are themselves represented by cards that come from your hand.

name: Corellian Pitch
notes: A Pitch variation by Larry Charbonneau

name: Coronation
notes: A Kings Corners variation for two players by David Stiefel.

name: Countdown
notes: An arithmetical game inspired by a TV game show, contributed by Matthew Arnold.

name: Counter
notes: An exact bidding game by Ben Meulink in which all the cards have special effects.

name: Counterweight
notes: An original two-player game by Adrian Morgan, in which the object is to get rid of your cards by discarding them in balanced pairs onto discard piles.

name: Coup D'Etat for 2 Players
notes: A variant for two players of the Parker Brothers game Coup d'Etat, contributed by Andrew Fischer.

name: Court
notes: A game by Robert Kalin based closely on the Japanese flower card game Koi Koi but with specially designed cards. Designs and rules can be downloaded here (court.zip).

name: Court Circular
notes: A sort of trick taking game for two or more players, invented by Lewis Caroll. Each player plays three times to each trick, and the winner of the trick is the player of the best combination.

name: Cowboy, Cowgirl, Cowpattie
notes: Poker variations contributed by txcubfan

name: Cramps
notes: A trick-taking game by Pete Caldwell, in which some tricks have a positive value, while others bring negative points.

name: Cranborne
notes: A two-player Rummy game by Richard Norris in which each player has two hands of cards played in succession and all discards are available for re-use.

name: CRAP
notes: CRAP stands for Challenge, Recycle, Aquire, and Protect, a quartet game contributed by Nathan Paziuk.

name: Craps
notes: A poker variation where cards are passed depending on the roll of a die, contributed by Ella Bowerman

name: Crash Cribbage
notes: Cribbage variation by Joe Kane in which players peg on a single track, and a peg landing on an opponent's peg sends the opponent forwards or backwards.

name: Crazy 3-5-7
notes: An alternative version of the poker variation 3-5-7 by Zac Pells.

name: Crazy 4 of Spades
notes: A draw poker variation by Ryan Turnbaugh with the 4 and sometimes other 4's wild.

name: Crazy Blind Man
notes: A version of Crazy Pineapple Poker where players see other players' cards, not their own, by Frank Kills In Water.

name: Crazy Cribbage
notes: A collection of cribbage variants by Trevor Orr with various hand sizes and numbers of players.

name: Crazy Dutchy
notes: A rapid fixed stake poker game by Ilya Bugreyev.

name: Crazy Jokers
notes: A draw and discard game in which each player tries to complete a contract of their choice, by Justin Huneke.

name: Crazy Pairs
notes: A Crazy Eights variation by Albert York.

name: Crazy Twenties, The
notes: A Phase 10 variation by Gabriele Scott.

name: Cribbage 31
notes: A Cribbage variant with additional scoring combinations, by Russell Sturges.

name: Cribbage Solitaire
notes: Play cribbage against the deck. Contributed by Natty Bumppo.

name: Cribbage with Jokers
notes: One of a series of Cribbage variations submitted from Queensland, Australia by Charlie Frost.

name: Cribbage with Jokers
notes: Contributed by Damien Blond of eCribbage.com

name: Cribbage with Jokers
notes: A Cribbage variant by Chris Mulhall using a 52-card pack plus 2 wild jokers.

name: Cribbage with Two Cut Cards
notes: One of a series of Cribbage variations submitted from Queensland, Australia by Charlie Frost.

name: Cribbeach
notes: A game based on Cribbage, by Andy Lewicki.

name: Cribbridge
notes: A Cribbage variant with 13 card hands, by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Cricket
notes: A solo cricket card game by Adam Lambert

name: Cricket Card
notes: A reasonably quick two-player game on the theme of a cricket test match, by Matthew Shields

name: Crime Wars
notes: A combat game for 2 to 4 players, by Brian Verchot.

name: Cripple Mr Onion
notes: A reconstruction of a fictional card game from Terry Pratchett's Discworld novels. Another, fuller set of rules is available here.

name: CrissCross
notes: A domino solitaire game by Chris Smyth

name: Crocodile
notes: A simplified version of Danish l'Hombre by Jakob Sauntved.

name: Croquet
notes: A Golf variation by Daniel Czech.

name: Cucamonga
notes: A shared card poker variant by Douglas Wall.

name: Curdle
notes: A shedding game by Aaron Hopewell, in which the difference in value between two cards determines what cards can be played next.

name: Currency
notes: A Crazy Eights variant by Cody O'Brien Grondin.

name: Cut-Throat Uno
notes: An Uno variation by Frank Soukey.

name: CutThroat
notes: A collection of Shithead variations by John Green.

name: Damn
notes: A shedding game by necronox.

name: Dancing Dragons
notes: A connecting game played with a set of 32 Chinese dominoes, developed by the Domino 32 Company in the late 20th century.

name: Dawn
notes: A game by Nick Reid in which players try to eliminate all the black cards from their hands.

name: Daytona
notes: A motor race game using a track made from playing cards, by James Thomas.

name: Dead Deuce
notes: A 7-card stud variant by Harry Carter in which only face up deuces are wild.

name: Deadly Spades
notes: A game by Sonja Ritter with some resemblance to Beggar My Neighbour or Egyptian Ratscrew, in which the aim is not to collect cards but to get rid of them.

name: Deadly Uno
notes: An Uno variation by Isaac Kuo.

name: Dealer Picks the Suit
notes: Oh Hell! variant by Andrew Hunt in which the dealer chooses trumps.

name: Decktet
notes: A special deck of 36 cards designed by P.D. Magnus. There are 6 suits but cards of rank 2 to 9 belong to two suits each. The card images are free to dowload from the web site, which also gives rules for around a dozen games played with these cards.

name: Deer Park Euchre
notes: A Buck Euchre variant contributed by Tom Bennett.

name: Defeat Dummy Dealer
notes: A solitaire Cribbage game by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Delaware Stud
notes: A Stud / Omaha-Hold'em poker hybrid, contributed by Mr. White

name: Depot
notes: A community card poker variant by George Weissenberger with an 8-card layout and an extra poker combination - the "ticket".

name: Determinism
notes: A game by 'Trick Slattery in which players score points by adding cards to an expanding layout.

name: Detonator
notes: The inventor Jarrid Steward describes this as a War variation but in fact it is a round game in which each player must beat the previous card or pick up a card as a penalty. Certain detonator plays allow cards from the play pile to be given to opponents.

name: Deuces Aren't Wild
notes: A variation of 3-13 rummy by Jared Mellentine.

name: Devil's Hand
notes: Contributed by Aaron Barnhart - players bet on whose hand is closest in value to a face-up hand on the table.

name: DFDD Reloaded
notes: DFDD (Demons From a Different Dimension) is a combat game using special cards, which can be downloaded free from its web site and printed at home.

name: Diamond
notes: A card game for 2-3 players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which you play cards to a diamond-shaped board in such a way that your opponent cannot.

name: Diamond Heist
notes: A solitaire game by Greg Jewell in which the A-9 of diamonds are to be arranged into a magic square by swapping pairs of cards under control of a Jack.

name: Diamonds
notes: A trick taking game similar to Oh Hell!, by Chris Donges.

name: Diamonds
notes: A kind of trick taking game in which diamonds are especially valuable, by Danny Patterson.

name: Dice and Dominoes
notes: A domino game in which players aim to get rid of their dominoes by discarding tiles whose ends match one or both dice.

name: Dice Card Mill
notes: A set of variations by Bill Perkins of his Squaressi games, in which a die is rolled at each turn to determine how many cards the player should draw from the stock.

name: Diominoes
notes: A game by Chris Smyth in which players use dominoes to match a roll of two dice.

name: Dirty Deals
notes: A four-player game by Matthew Shields. This is a trick-taking game with recycling (completed tricks are added to the trick-winner's hand) in which the object is to collect a complete suit while avoiding other suits, possibly with the support of an opponent.

name: Ditch Rummy
notes: A rummy game by Gabriel Arthur Petrie in which players never hold more than three cards and can discard as many cards as they wish.

name: Divide and Conquer
notes: A GOPS variant using 10 dominoes, adapted from a card game designed by Claude Soucie.

name: Dix
notes: A two-player game by Fred Blundun in which the object is to win tricks, but avoid tricks whose pip cards add up to 10.

name: Dollars from Heaven
notes: A variation of Pennies from Heaven by Noel McClintock.

name: Dom
notes: One of Keith Stevens' new card games. Two players play alternately to a 4x4 layout and score for card combinations in the row and column where the new card is played.

name: Domijong
notes: A mahjong-like game by Bob Richards using 4 sets of 6-6 dominoes.

name: Dominion
notes: A card and dice game for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. This is a strategy game in which you maneuver your armies and try to capture enemy territories.

name: Domino Bead Game
notes: A game by Sid Sackson in which dominoes are played to build a grid containing repeating patterns.

name: Domino Golf
notes: A golf simulation for two players, using a double 12 domino set, by Andrew Fischer.

name: Domino Roads
notes: A game for four (or three) players using dominoes and dice, by Joel Zimmerman.

name: Dominoes Freecell Solitaire
notes: An adaptation for dominoes of Freecell card solitaire by Ecks Why.

name: Dominoes-Matrix
notes: A domino game by Mal Jones with matador-style connection rules in which players score for surrounding empty spaces.

name: Domizerka
notes: A trick-taking domino game by Kantaphon Tongmee, based on the Polish game Mizerka, but with domino trick taking rules as in 42 or Moon.

name: Dōng Xī Mahjong
notes: A Mahjong variant for 2 to 6 players based on Asian versions of the game but using an American set of 152 tiles, contributed by Bob Richards.

name: Doogie
notes: A poker variation related to badugi, contributed by Bob and Robin Procter.

name: Doomcrop
notes: A combat game by Riley Adamson in which each player has nine cards in a 3x3 grid which can attack corresponding cards in the opponent's grid.

name: Doors
notes: A simple solitaire game, contributed by Joe Wolf

name: Double Deck Cribbage
notes: One of a series of Cribbage variations submitted from Queensland, Australia by Charlie Frost.

name: Double Elevator
notes: A shared card poker game by Charles Pierce.

name: Double Joker
notes: A 2-player game by Angus Benedek in which players must avoid winning tricks whilst also rationing their cards.

name: Double Takes
notes: A trick-taking game by David Galt using a [15-15] domino set. Doubles are permanent trumps.

name: Double Trouble
notes: A complicated variation of Bridge, played with two packs mixed together, invented by Matti Jantunen

name: Double Trouble
notes: A poker variation in which players divide their hands into two, contributed by Bryant Woodard.

name: Double-Edge Trim-Saw
notes: A Texas Hold'Em Poker variation by Chris Odell, also known as Texas Trim.

name: Doubles in the Boneyard
notes: A three-player domino game by Jose Carrillo.

name: Doubly Reversed Shithead With Double Sampling
notes: A Shithead variation by James Hollidge.

name: Dracula
notes: A game for two to four players by David Parlett, in which cards are played to a 3x3 layout with the aim of forming high-scoring rows or columns.

name: Draft
notes: A solitaire game by Aaron Barnhart.

name: Draft Cribbage
notes: A four-player Cribbage variation by David Brain, in which some cards are passed around the table before the play.

name: Dragon Hearts
notes: A Hearts variant by Steve Mohr with three jokers, two high and one low.

name: Draw Cribbage
notes: One of a series of Cribbage variations submitted from Queensland, Australia by Charlie Frost.

name: Duck Soup
notes: A trick-taking game for two players in two stages (courses), by David Parlett. In the first course (duck) the lower card of the suit led wins, and in the second (soup) the higher card wins; it is also possible to win tricks in either course with a card of equal rank to the lead.

name: Duel
notes: A two-player combat game by Mark Brown, which emulates the popular commercial CCG Magic: the Gathering using a regular deck of playing cards.

name: Duel
notes: A combat game by Áron Csathó, inspired by U-G-O by Michael Daniel and the TSR card game Blood Wars.

name: Duel
notes: A combat game inspired by Yu-Gi-Oh!, invented by Norbert Steinkellner.

name: Duel 52
notes: A 2-player combat game by Judd Madden using a standard 52-card pack. The aim is to win two of the three lanes in which card battles take place.

name: Duel King
notes: A War variation by Chris Alexander and Jeremy L Minney.

name: Duel of Fives
notes: A two-player game by Jesse Weinstein, in which each simultaneously plays five cards at a time, with the object of winning the majority of the comparisons.

name: Dummy Hand Spades
notes: A 3-player Spades variation by Dan Corkill in which one hand is played as a dummy in a similar way to Bridge.

name: Dummy Hearts
notes: A three-player Hearts variant by George Wang, in which players bid for control of the dummy.

name: Dureń Piątkowy
notes: A mixture of Dureń and Dureń Piątkowy.

name: Dvorak
notes: A flexible game played with home-made cards, most of which represent actions (played to the discard pile) or things (played in front of the player). Players take turns to play an action and/or a thing from their five card hand and then draw replacement cards from the stock. The effect of each card is written on it. The web site contains some ready-made card designs that can be used, and the players can cards of their own invention or design a whole new deck from scratch.

name: Eagles, Birdies and Holes in One
notes: Four-card Golf variants by Mike Morgan.

name: East Point
notes: A revised, rationalised and expanded version of two player pinochle, by Dave Barber

name: Eddie's Choice
notes: A variation of 7 card stud, contributed by Dan Mathe, in which a down card matched with an up card becomes wild.

name: Effervesce
notes: A trading card game for 2-7 players by Clark DeCant, in which the aim is to collect a complete suit without duplicates.

name: Egyptian Hold'em
notes: A Texas Hold 'Em Poker variant by David Morrah with 6-card hands and 6 community cards.

name: Eight-Suit Crazy Eights
notes: A Crazy Eights variant by Ben Andrews using an 8-suited, 104-card deck.

name: El Dorado Hold'em
notes: A Texas Hold 'Em Poker variant by Tony Forbess in which players can exchange a card with the flop to make it wild.

name: Elemental
notes: A solitaire game by Adrian Morgan in which the aim is to remove cards from a layout in blocks of four all of different suits. The game can be played on line at the web site.

name: Elimination
notes: A game contributed by Arthur Buderick, in which players bet on who has the highest or lowest total of card values in a hand of five cards from which some have been eliminated.

name: Elimination Uno
notes: An Uno variation by Allen J Price, in which the winner is the last player left in rather than the first player out.

name: elroyale
notes: A card game by Adomas Milius consisting of a series of battles between two players, in which the aim is to play the fourth equal card to a battle as your last card.

name: Empires
notes: A combat game by Daniel Caton, in which each player has a 52-card pack of soldiers (spades), defenders (hearts), spells (clubs) and resources (diamonds).

name: Ena
notes: A Slovenian Uno variation, contributed by Wei-Hwa Huang.

name: EnD320
notes: A vying game by Kawsar Uddin, in which players discard and replace cards to achieve the high scoring hand.

name: Engine 191
notes: A domino game for 2-4 players by Tim Schutz (tjgames).

name: English Sets
notes: An automatic game by Bella Atkins in which two players compete to collect set of four of a kind.

name: Enhanced Uno
notes: Enhanced rules for the commerical game Uno, contributed by Paul Bryant.

name: Epidemic
notes: A trick avoidance game by Florent Barraco in which the object is to avoid taking tricks containing "virus" cards.

name: Epsom
notes: A two-player version of Newmarket, contributed by John Wright.

name: Equilibrium Joker
notes: A War variant by John Peterson.

name: Escalation
notes: A card game by Charles Pierce in which you must either beat the previously played card or set or take the play pile as penalty cards.

name: Estimation Hearts
notes: A hybrid of Hearts and Oh Hell!, contributed by Mark Brader.

name: Estonian Twist
notes: A rapid fixed stake poker game by Ilya Bugreyev.

name: Euchre Solitaire
notes: Euchre for one player, by Natty Bumppo.

name: Euronimoes
notes: A domino game by Dave Ross in which each player has their own grid where they play tiles to form sequential runs in the columns. The score for a run is the lowest number in it, and the aim is to have as low a score as possible. Players also have chips with which they can buy dominoes from a 'market'.

name: Evil Deal
notes: A trick taking game for two players, each with their own trump suit, by Jørgen Ravn Hagen.

name: Evil Spades
notes: Rules for a series of hands of Spades each with different constraints on the bidding or play.

name: Evil Uno
notes: An Uno variation contributed by Linda Stahnke.

name: Exploding Aces
notes: A game by Luigi Skull in which players try to avoid being caught holding an Ace.

name: Exposure
notes: A two-player trick-taking card game by Matthew Shields, in which players can score bonus points by exposing combinations before the play.

name: Extra Card
notes: Oh Hell! variant by Andrew Hunt in which an extra card is dealt if the total of the bids matches the hand size.

name: Exxodus
notes: A space themed combat card game by Daniel Sandner. It requires a special deck of cards which can be printed from the designs on the web site.

name: Faces of Death
notes: A stud poker variant by Fran

name: Fan Rummy
notes: A Gin Rummy variant played with exposed stock cards, contributed by Daniel Friedman.

name: Fano
notes: A combat game by Will Hansen in which attacks use a rock-paper-scissors principle based on lines in the 7-point Fano plane.

name: Fashion
notes: A card stacking game for 2 to 4 players by Mason Yeater.

name: Fast Break Cribbage
notes: A four-player Cribbage variation by Richard Everett

name: Fast Cash Jack
notes: A multi-player casino game based on Blackjack by John Picken. Several players ante to a pot and play against Blackjack against the house, losing a life when they fail to win or tie a hand. The last player left in wins the pot.

name: Fast Food
notes: An adding game by Dan Wakefield

name: Fat Buddah
notes: A crazy eights variation by Peter Ipnar.

name: Feud
notes: An epic combat card game for two players, by Jonathan Dobson.

name: Fib-Fibonacci
notes: A two-player game by Eric Treadwell and T.J. Highley using 26 cards left over from a Euchre game. Players compete to get rid of their cards by playing them in "runs" that follow the principles of Fibonacci sequences.

name: Fibonacci
notes: A two-player game by Simon and Niklas Indola in which cards can be played if they match the sum of the top cards on two or three piles.

name: Fierce
notes: A guts variation by Mike Simmons.

name: Fifteen
notes: A game based loosely on All Fives and having a crib like Cribbage, contributed by Curtis Jones.

name: Fifteen Thirty_five
notes: A variant of 7-27 contributed by Arthur Buderick as an option in Dealer's Choice Poker in which players bet on whose hand has a total value closest to 15 or 35.

name: Fifty Plus/Minus
notes: A game of addition and subtraction contributed by Brian Stovel and invented by his grand-daughter Dani.

name: Fifty-two
notes: A two-player draw and discard game by Justin Howlett in which players try to collect five cards of one suit.

name: Fight for the Lead
notes: A game of the Rams group without trumps, contributed by Jay Noack.

name: Fighting Cards
notes: A three-player point trick game with bidding, contributed by Zhuzhu.

name: Finesse
notes: An ingenious and well balanced trick-taking game for four players in fixed partnerships, by Miles Edward Allen. Each player begins with 13 cards in hand and three cards face up on the table; when leading to a trick you can choose between leading one of your hand cards or one of partner's face up cards, which partner must replace from hand at the end of the trick.

name: Finish Line
notes: A card and dice game from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. This feels like a board game, in which players race along an obstacle-laden path of playing cards to the finish line.

name: Finnish 27™
notes: A series of adding games by Kevin Michael McDaniel in which the object is to make a hand totalling as near as possible to 27 counting aces as 1 or 14, Kings 13, Queens 12 and Jacks 11, the picture card values corresponding to their indices in a standard Finnish deck.

name: Fire
notes: A War variation by Dan The Man.

name: Fireplace Poker
notes: A two player card game by Tuomas Korppi in which players steal cards from their opponent's poker hands to complete their own better poker hands.

name: Five and Two or Three
notes: A poker variation of the guts type, contributed by Phil Boschert.

name: Five Card Roll Your Own
notes: A 5-Card Stud Poker variant by David DeLine.

name: Five Crowns Bridge
notes: A Bridge variant by Stephen Rogers using half a Five Crowns deck - 5 suits of 11 cards plus a joker.

name: Five Numbers Game
notes: A game by Robbie Rosman, formerly known as 'The Math Game', in which players try to reach a given total by means of arithmetical operations on a set of 5 cards. It differs from 24 in that the target total is variable and each player has their own set of cards to work with.

name: Five-card Double Draw High-Low
notes: A poker variant by Chris Hood.

name: Five-card Open Draw (sequential)
notes: A Draw Poker variant with open discards, by Bruce Leban.

name: Five-card Open Draw (simple)
notes: A Draw Poker variant with open discards, by Bruce Leban.

name: Five-Card Pinochle
notes: A fast Pinochle game with a 40-card pack, suitable for two or more players, contributed by John Sroufe.

name: Five-Card Rummy
notes: A draw and discard game in which the aim is to make a poker hand, contributed by C2K.

name: Five-Handed Call Queen Euchre
notes: A 5-player Euchre variant by Evan Wachter in which the trump maker chooses a partner by calling the Queen of trumps.

name: Five-Hundred++
notes: An Australian 500 variation by Brad Tonkes.

name: Fives
notes: A draw poker variant with buying, by Don Cunningham.

name: Flaming Cross
notes: An Iron Cross Poker variant contributed by Arthur Buderick.

name: Flip Ace
notes: A variant of the Solitaire game "Aces Up", contributed by Kewlio.

name: Flip/Switch Double Deck Euchre
notes: A Euchre variant for 2-10 players in which the trump suit can be changed during the play, contributed by Nathaniel Burgett.

name: Flop-A
notes: A betting game by Brian Odell.

name: Flushed
notes: A shedding game by Michael Velker in which you must follow suit or pick up the play pile.

name: Follow the Leader
notes: A simple game for 2 to 5 players by Chris Goodman. Each card played must be equal to or one higher than the previous play, and the object is to get rid of all your cards.

name: Foolery
notes: A cross between President and Big Two, played with a 78-card Tarot pack, contributed by Jared McComb.

name: Fools Gold
notes: A trick-taking game by David Nijjar, in which the aim is to win tricks in one suit, avoiding tricks in the others.

name: Football
notes: A poker-style betting game based on American Football, contributed by Tim Beaulieu.

name: Football (3)
notes: A seven card stud poker variant by John Noriega.

name: Forty-Three
notes: A shared card poker variant by Bob Procter.

name: Fotboll
notes: A football simulation with a regular deck of cards.

name: Foundations
notes: A solitaire game with a wild card, contributed by Franklin Newman.

name: Four Aces
notes: A draw and discard game by Jeff Ferraro in which players try to form combinations in two hands, one hidden and one exposed.

name: Four Aces
notes: A straightforward two-player game by Vincent Launchbury in which the object is to collect all four aces by playing face cards and jokers as action cards.

name: Four Card Draw
notes: A game of pure chance by Mike Clendenen, in which the players compare 4-card hands and the player with the best scoring combinations wins.

name: Four Fucks Sake
notes: A "more vicious" version of Shithead, contributed by Sean Clark.

name: Four Kingdoms
notes: A trick taking card game by Mikael Sauren for 3-4 players (also playable by 2, 5 or 6) in which the strategies and meanings of cards can very greatly from one deal to the next, because of the mechanisms of the 'king deck' that determines the scoring.

name: Four Queens
notes: A hearts variation by Paul Hoemke in which all four queens affect the scoring.

name: Four Rows
notes: A strategy game by Michael Tizzano in which players try to get rid of their cards by playing them on four piles, matching the rank of the previous card or playing the next higher or lower rank of the same suit.

name: Four Royalties
notes: A quick game in which players try to get rid of their cards by playing them on four-card columns; the cards in each column must be in descending order. Contributed by Andrew Zhou.

name: Four Sisters
notes: A kind of combat game for four players in two partnerships, by Chris Goodwin. Conflicts take place in a central 3x3 array into which players can play cards.

name: Four Suit Rummy
notes: A two-player rummy variation by Paul Markwick in which players try to collect a run in each suit.

name: Four Up, Four Down
notes: An eight-card stud poker variant by Robert Dier.

name: Four Virtues of Royalty
notes: A two-player Rummy game by Neal Lyons in which the face cards have special effects.

name: Four-Card Noddy
notes: A Noddy variation by Jonny Groves

name: Foxtrot
notes: A game by Ed Vasicek, based on the Turkish game Pishti.

name: Fracas
notes: A combat card game for two players by Dan Shahin, based on some of the principles of Magic the Gathering and War but using standard playing-cards.

name: Frak You
notes: A trick-taking game by Josiah Brock, Matthew Forsthoefel, and Christopher Hendry in which players who win tricks add the cards to their hands, but the object is to get rid of cards.

name: Freak of Nature
notes: A poker variation by Doble J.

name: Freak Solitaire
notes: An original solitaire game by Michael Gurfinkel

name: Fred Potato
notes: A variation of Hold'em contributed by Jim De Rosa.

name: Freestate
notes: A game by Steve Kramer in which the object is to discard all of your cards, following suit where possible while keeping the total point value of cards played at 15 or under; a player who exceeds 15 must pick up the discard pile.

name: Galactic War
notes: A war variation by Lee Walker in which suits play a part in battles.

name: Galapagos
notes: A leisurely two player game by David Parlett, consisting of a melding phase, followed by a trick-taking phase, followed by a phase where you try to get rid of your cards.

name: Galaxy
notes: This game by Ben Humphries uses an unusual combination of trick taking and melding - the aim is to get rid of cards from your hand in melds (consisting of a 'planet' and 'moons'), but the way you collect the cards you need for melds is by using your unmelded cards to play tricks, and acquiring repacement cards as prizes.

name: Gambling Spades
notes: A Spades variation for 3 to 6 players by Rob McDiarmid, in which the highest scorer in each hand wins the pot.

name: Game
notes: A combat game for 2-4 players by Daniel Calizaya in which players attack each other's armies and defend their own by presenting groups of cards from their hands with the appropriate total value.

name: General's War
notes: A combat game loosely based on War, by Alex Jansen.

name: Get the Nines
notes: A sort of trick taking game for three players with simultaneous play, by JJ Williamson. The objective is to collect all the nines.

name: Ghost
notes: A Shithead variation by Sean Burns, Chris Johnson, Nirmal Shaw and Dylan Riddle in which cards are played face down and the player can lie about their value.

name: Gifts and Blessings
notes: A two-player game by Michael Camarata in which players give each other cards.

name: Gin Bummy
notes: A draw and discard game for 2-4 players by John Baulding, in which players start with 10 cards and try to reduce their hand to four numeral cards with no two of the same rank or suit.

name: Gin Dice
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Pro
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Race
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Rainbow
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Rush
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Shot
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Gin Twofold
notes: Gin Rummy variant by Andrzej Lewicki.

name: Give & Take
notes: A War variation for 2 to 4 players by Jordan Goldstein in which battle results are based on the differences between cards played by adjacent players.

name: Give It Away Now
notes: A round game by Troy Hinkley in which players take turns to draw a card and then, depending on its value, draw further cards, give cards away, or initiate a forfeit round, the aim being to have fewest cards at the end.

name: Give Two
notes: Uno variant by Diana Crain.

name: Giza
notes: A Solitaire card game by Michael Keller, based on Pyramid but with all cards exposed at the start making it into a puzzle along the lines of Freecell.

name: Glup Pinochle
notes: A two-player Pinochle variant contributed by 'Mouse', which features larger hands than in the traditional game, more melds, and 'glups' which are scored for losing several consecutive tricks by following suit.

name: Go Fish Deluxe
notes: A Go Fish variation invented and contributed by Jonny Groves.

name: Go Fishing
notes: A cross between Hand and Foot and Go Fish, contributed  by Kate and Jess.

name: Goldmine
notes: A two-player game by Jared, in which players try to draw scoring cards from a face-down layout.

name: Good King, Bad Queen
notes: A War variation by Ed Vasicek

name: Gossiper
notes: A two-player card game by Julius the Jules, in which players take turns to flip a card from the deck and may try to buy it by flipping a matching card within a limited number of tries.

name: Guerilla Joker
notes: A War variation by Ryan Hill

name: Guess That Card
notes: A betting game by Nick Harrison; one card is dealt to each player and one face down to the table; in a showdown the closest to the face down card wins.

name: Guillotine
notes: A game of the King / Barbu type, invented by Scott Marley.

name: Gurfinkel Deal
notes: A Tien Len variant by by Michael Gurfinkel.

name: Habitual Joker
notes: A two-player game by Simon Bates.

name: Half and Half
notes: A simple game of chance by Mitch Newlin.

name: Hang Ten
notes: A variant of ten-card Golf in which each player has their own discard pile, contributed by Douglas Wall.

name: Harvest
notes: A game by Kyle King for 2-4 players who compete to place cards representing the planting, tending and harvesting of crops represented by the four suits.

name: Head to Head
notes: A variation of GOPS by Warren Esty.

name: Hearts Poker
notes: A poker variant by Jack Namazukage.

name: Hearts++
notes: A Hearts variation with addtional scoring cards, passing options and moon-shooting options by Brad Tonkes.

name: Hebrac's Dungeon
notes: A role-playing game for one player using two or more standard decks, by Luc Miron.

name: Herbie
notes: A Guts variation with a spare hand, contributed (but not invented) by Matt Preston.

name: High Card
notes: An original game for 2-13 players who try to estimate whether the card they are playing is the highest, lowest or in the middle, invented by Chris Gesell and Jason Christie and contributed by Guy Srinivasan.

name: High Card Low Card
notes: A game of psychology by Chris Eversman in which players try to choose a card different from all the other players.

name: High Card Poker
notes: A poker variant by Andy Drew.

name: High Fives
notes: A fishing game by David Galt, using a [15-15] domino set.

name: High Jinks
notes: A combat card game for 2 to 4 players by Justin Elkan Jones, using standard playing-cards. A lite version for beginners is also available.

name: High-Die
notes: A 5-card Draw Poker variation contributed by Mike Thompson.

name: High-Low Chicago
notes: A poker variant contributed by Josh Breid

name: High/Low Spades
notes: A Spades variant by Elsa Edwards, in which the leader to a trick can determine whether the highest or lowest card will win it.

name: Hit The Deck!
notes: A 2-player abstraction of a naval battle using a standard 52-card deck, by Calixtus Ashley Wee.

name: Hockey
notes: A simplified four-player variant of the Canadian game Hockey by Scott Schemahorn, in which matching the previous player's card scores an immediate goal.

name: Hockey
notes: This game by Michael Bryson simulates not just a single game but several years of managing a hockey team, with league play, playoffs and drafting, retirement and trading of players.

name: Hold Up
notes: An automatic game of turning over cards, contibuted by Florent Barraco.

name: Hold'Em Uno
notes: An Uno variation by Charles.

name: Hole in the Wall
notes: A game for two to four players by Mal T Jones in which cards are played in sequences to build a wall with extra scores for forming holes.

name: Hole of Mana
notes: A quick two-player game by Joseph D. Smith in which players try to eliminate each other's suits.

name: Hollywood Hold'em
notes: A Texas Hold'em Poker variation by Brian J. Cavanaugh.

name: Homo Homini Lupus
notes: A cross domino game in which doubles can be used to block an arm of the layout.

name: Honeymoon Whist
notes: A variant by of German Whist, using two jokers, by Jonny Groves.

name: Honor of the Samurai
notes: A battle game by Obinna Onwuka.

name: Horn-A-Vika
notes: A Seven-card Stud Poker variant from Arthur Buderick with an extra shared 'spit' card, in which players with a pair on the board must match the pot to stay in.

name: Hornipex
notes: A shedding card game by Kyle Hoffmaier in which the playable cards are governed by an elaborate set of connection rules.

name: Horseshoe
notes: A 2-player trick-taking card game from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which not all cards are known at the outset, and pairs trump all else.

name: Hot
notes: A variation of Tyler McCarn's "Collector", contributed by Trevor Cuthbertson

name: Hot Death Uno
notes: Uno variation using at least two decks and many additional special cards created by altering some of the original cards. Features strong language and profanity.

name: Hot Tip
notes: Poker variation by Courtney Crowley. Uses language that some readers may find offensive. Rules here.

name: House Rules Card UNO
notes: Uno variation by Steven Beard.

name: How Low Can You Go?
notes: A straightforward game by Jack Whalen, in which the aim is to have the lowest total point value in a five-card hand after exchanging cards up to three times.

name: Hungarian War
notes: A party card game by Lauren Schlick in which players use dice to try to take cards from a layout or block others from taking them.

name: Hurricane Spades
notes: A Spades variant in which cards are passed before the bidding.

name: Huse Hearts for Two
notes: An interesting two-player version of Hearts with a dummy hand, contributed by Gordon Huse.

name: Iceberg
notes: A Rummy variation for 2-4 players by Gordon Bower. Another description of Iceberg is available on Howard Fosdick's page.

name: Identity
notes: A memory game by Romain Tello.

name: Immunity
notes: A game by Don Smith in which players score by playing cards on opponents' layouts and try to achieve immunity in their own layouts to make it difficult for opponents to place cards there.

name: Imperium
notes: A two-player trick-taking game with a 17-card deck, contributed by Erich Burkhardt.

name: In The Red
notes: A game by Ken Elmer in which each player has a play pile on which cards are played matching rank or suit, and players try to avoid having the highest red card showing.

name: Indian Chief
notes: A poker variant by Patrick St-Louis.

name: Insurance Hearts
notes: A Hearts variation by Daniel Calizaya, with options to insure against taking the Q, to bid for a choice of 13th card, and to cancel a deal.

name: Ipso
notes: A gambling card game for 2 to 5 players using four-card hands, invented by Stephen Bradbury.

name: Island Pineapple
notes: A shared card poker variant by Trevor Cuthbertson.

name: Italian Whist
notes: A trick-taking game for three players by  by A. Chart, S. Drew and T. Phipps.

name: J-Lo
notes: A poker variant by Dana Collins - a combination of Jacks or Better with Deuce to Seven Lowball.

name: J.K. Flush
notes: A draw and discard game by Jamie Masculine in which the object is to collect a 7-card run in a suit.

name: Jaago-Chalis
notes: A four-player trick-taking game in which each suit trumps the other suit of the same colour, from the J-40 development team in Nepal.

name: Jack in the Box
notes: A game by Mal T Jones for up to four players. Players score by playing cards that match the cards of a box-shaped layout.

name: Jackpot
notes: A showdown game by Mike J, in which the size of the pot is determined by the cards discarded by the players while improving their hands.

name: Jackpot
notes: A Poker variation by Matt Molver in which all players may repeatedly discard a card and draw a replacement.

name: Jailbreak
notes: A distant relative of War, by Tom Acker, in which players try to assemble the most valuable collection of prisoners.

name: Jam
notes: A rapid trick-taking game for two players by Matthew Shields, in which one player plays with red cards and the other with black.

name: Jambo
notes: A Go Fish variant by Alex Chase and Ankit Vohra in which you can see other players' cards but not your own.

name: Jamón
notes: A round game of uncertain origin, contributed by Joel Cross.

name: Jemima Puddle Duck
notes: A draw and discard game by Jilly McZee in which, by eliminating sets of four equal cards, players try to reduce their hands to fewer than four cards.

name: Jersey Holdem
notes: A variation of Omaha High Low 8 or Better Poker by Mike Picollelli, formerly known as Cosmic Poker.

name: Jewel
notes: A game of the rummy family with special combinations and fairly complex scoring, by Basudeo Agarwal.

name: Ji'zara
notes: A game by Micheal Clark for two or four players, who use cards from their hand to bid for cards from a draw pile.

name: Joker Hearts
notes: A Hearts variation with jokers, by Jonathan Crawford.

name: Joker High
notes: A trick-taking game with bidding, somewhat similar to 500, contributed by Michael Lawson.

name: Joker High
notes: Oh Hell! variant by Andrew Hunt with a joker ranking as highest trump.

name: Joker Rum
notes: A Rummy-like game by Kishor Gordhandas.

name: Joker's Dagger
notes: A War variation by Michayla Gussler.

name: Jokers
notes: A two-player game by Gavin Clarke, similar to rummy but with a different draw and discard mechanism and scoring system.

name: Jokers and Nines
notes: A Crazy Eights variant by Jonny Groves

name: Jokers Kill
notes: A game of chance by Trevin Cowman in which players score points if they are dealt the lowest card or a card matching a face up card on the table.

name: Jokers of Death
notes: A Crazy Eights variant with three discard piles by José Luis Adrião - also known as Insane Eights.

name: Jummy
notes: A Rummy variation contributed by Skabok.

name: Jungle
notes: A 2-player card game from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. This is exploration game, where players explore a jungle of playing cards, compete over treasures, and have a showdown at the end.

name: Junk
notes: A simple yet difficult solitaire game by Diego Crawford.

name: Jynx
notes: A game of luck, in which you hope not to turn over jynxed cards.

name: K'nack
notes: A game by Michael Camarata in which players try to get rid of cards by playing them to a layout in which adjacent cards must be opposite in colour and one different in rank. A solitaire version is also available.

name: Kansas Tornado
notes: An Omaha Poker variant by Chris Gaskill.

name: Kardball
notes: A baseball simulation played between two teams of players with a standard 52-card pack, invented by Jeffrey Pierce.

name: Keep Trying
notes: A card game by Charles Pierce in which the player of the best set wins a stake and an extra card for their hand.

name: Kemetic Unorthodox Rat Screw (K.U.R.S.)
notes: An Egyptian Ratscrew variant from Entropic Trinity, played with a 78-card Tarot pack in which the trumps and the fool have special effects.

name: Kendra Kari
notes: A game by Adrian Morgan designed to be played with circular Indian ganjifa cards, a 96-card pack with 8 suits of 12 cards. It is a shedding game in which the cards are played to 7 positions: a ring of 6 with a 7th in the centre.

name: Kill
notes: A game for four players by Eden Cohen in which players try to build a winning hand of K-Q-J-10 of one colour by exchanging cards according to certain rules.

name: Killer Kings
notes: A drinking game by HughGrahamFarms.

name: King Cut-Throat Euchre
notes: A Euchre variant by Chuck Barr.

name: King George III
notes: A simple shedding game in which each card played must be equal or adjacent to the previous one, contributed by Rob and Dan.

name: King Weirdo
notes: A draw and discard game in which players use the cards in their hands to build columns in alternating colours from the king downwards, as in a solitaire game. Contributed by John Capozella.

name: King's Pot
notes: A poker variant in which players bet on progressively revealed hands in a 5x5 layout without knowing which hands belong to the other players, contributed by Alan Kross-Vinson.

name: Klitzkie Family Uno
notes: An Uno variation contributed by Penny Klitzkie and David Hoelzel.

name: Klondike
notes: An original domino game by Arne Matschinsky in which the tiles are played to a grid and chips are won by surrounding a node of the grid.

name: Kong-Pie
notes: An unusual draw and discard game by Gabriel Arthur Petrie in which players collect combinations known as Kongs.

name: Königrufen with a Dummy
notes: Three-player Königrufen with a dummy hand, an adaptation of the 4-player Austrian Tarock game.

name: Koper
notes: A two-player game by James Walsh in which the cards are laid out to form a board around which checkers are moved Halma-style and poker hands formed from the spaces occupied by a player's pieces.

name: KRG
notes: A shared card poker game played for fixed stakes, contributed by Chris Hoogstad.

name: Kryky
notes: A shared card poker variant contributed by Tim Bates.

name: La Krap
notes: An unusual trick-taking game, in which cards often neutralise each other, contributed by Paavo Suhonen.

name: La Morte
notes: A trick-taking game for 3-5 players by Matt Haller with a special "death" card, which causes the player who wins a trick containing it to drop out of the play.

name: Last Chance
notes: A game based on Speed, by Ally Weller.

name: Laying the Smackdown
notes: A game of combinations based on wrestling, by Hugh Heelan.

name: Lead
notes: A plain-trick game in which the high bidder chooses a partner by calling a trump. Contributed by Cathy Artigues.

name: Liar Game
notes: A card game by Mark Christian Jr. consisting of a series of rounds in which each player selects a hand of three cards from six, saving the others for later rounds.

name: Liar, Liar
notes: A Rummy variation by Marc Bradley Zeedar in which you can ask for a card from an opponent instead of drawing from the stock or discard pile.

name: Lie Detector
notes: A game of intuition by Tom Austin in which the dealer tries to detect whether statements made by other players about the card they are holding are true or false.

name: Liege Lord
notes: A roll your own stud poker variant by Justin du Coeur, in which cards are passed to the left and the winner shares the pot with their right-hand opponent.

name: Limbo
notes: A combat game for 2-4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection.

name: Llechfan Bezique / Marjolet
notes: Bezique with extra scoring combinations from Marjolet added - contributed by Mal Jones.

name: Loc
notes: A betting game by Odo fitz Gilbert for 4 to 8 (or even 10) players, in which players choose in what order to play their cards and the pot is taken by an ace or joker.

name: Lockout
notes: A solitaire game created by Daniel R.

name: Loco
notes: A poker variant that does not require chips, from the Poker Bankroll Blog.

name: Looking for Twos
notes: A drinking game.

name: Losing Cribbage
notes: A negative version of cribbage, contributed by Dave and Jeff.

name: Love That Joker
notes: An Oh Hell! variation with wild jokers, by Ross Powell.

name: Low Card High Suit
notes: A shedding game for four players by Nicholas Bos

name: Low Hold
notes: A variation of 7 card stud poker, contributed by Dan Mathe, in which each player's lowest down card is wild.

name: Low-Die
notes: A 5-card Draw Poker variation contributed by Mike Thompson.

name: Lowball
notes: One of a series of Cribbage variations submitted from Queensland, Australia by Charlie Frost.

name: Lowball Guts
notes: Three-card Guts played for lowest hand, contributed by Chris Hood.

name: Lower Euchre
notes: American Euchre players use 28 cards: 24 to play with and four for scoring. Lower Euchre is a trick-taking game for three players using rest of the deck: the 24 unused lower cards and two jokers. Contributed by David Longhurst.

name: Luck of the Irish
notes: A Poker variation by Alan Frandsen.

name: Lucky House
notes: A rapid betting game with elements of trick taking and hold'em poker, by William Chamberlin.

name: Lucky-o
notes: A simple solitaire game of luck by Justin Huneke, in which the player tries to guess the suits of cards.

name: Ludens
notes: A trick-taking game for four players by Carlos De La Riva, in which the cards are divided into odds, evens and pictures, and tricks only score if they contain a sufficient quota of cards of the appropriate category.

name: Ludic
notes: A game by Jesse Fuchs is which players try to guess the dealer's secret rule for accepting or rejecting sets of cards.

name: Luris
notes: A game of strategy and bluff for 2-4 players by Jim Westergren in which players place partly concealed sets of four or more supposedly equal cards.

name: Mad Abel
notes: A 2-player game by Smári McCarthy, in which players get rid of sets of cards whose ranks and suits sum to a card designated by the previous two discards, adding suits modulo 4 and ranks modulo 13.

name: Magic Uno
notes: A variation of UNO, played using "Magic, the Gathering" cards, created by Enrique Medina.

name: Mahjong Poker
notes: A casino banking game using Mah Jong cards, invented by Wayne Hong.

name: Manager
notes: A simple two-player game by Matthew Shields representing a series of 11 football seasons between which new players can be drafted by exchanging cards.

name: Manzana Canasta
notes: A version of Canasta for two players using a single deck, invented by Paul Edwards.

name: Marijnissen
notes: A President variation contributed by Martin Hulsman.

name: Marshall Poker
notes: A 5-player game by Gary Thompson, in which players trade cards and then compare poker hands. The players with better hands have an advantage in the next deal and the object is to maintain top position (marshall) for five consecutive deals.

name: Marshmallow War
notes: A two-player combat game using two standard playing-card decks, by Will Gunther and Shawn Shadrix.

name: Masquerade Ball
notes: A game by Leigh Boyd using cards as pieces that move and attack as in an abstract board wargame, but whose capability is hidden when face down.

name: Mass Cool Casino
notes: A game for 2-8 players by Brian Sauer, loosely based on War but with a form of betting using cards as money.

name: Matchup 4
notes: A children's game in which players try to form matched pairs of cards, similar to memory / concentration but more elaborate, invented by Bradley Watson and named by Cameron Watson.

name: Mauna Kea
notes: A two-player game by Jesse Fuchs, in which players try to build a column of cards worth 100 points, which can be partly protected from attack by face cards used as 'pitons'.

name: Maverick
notes: A point trick game by Ben: players try to take cards in the 'adders' suit while avoiding taking trumps.

name: Mbogo
notes: Lacking the original rules, Richard Heli invented a new version of this game played with a 61 card pack depicting African animals, hunters and cages.

name: Mediocrity
notes: An unusual game by Greg Weidman, in which the object is to be the most mediocre player.

name: Memory
notes: A game by Keith Stewart in which players try to memorise a sequence of cards to predict whether the next card played will be higher or lower.

name: Mexican Standoff
notes: A trick avoidance card game for 3 - 4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection.

name: Milk Run
notes: A card game for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, where you must deliver chocolate and strawberry milk, while encumbering your opponents' ability to do so.

name: Milken
notes: A game by John Cooper, in which by playing cards to suit piles in the centre (representing the "market") you try to make the remaining cards in your hand worth more than other players' cards before the game ends.

name: Mines21
notes: A game by Jeremy Griffith, in which players build piles of cards following suit or rank, and capture them when the total value of cards in the pile reaches 21 or more.

name: Mini Mao
notes: A variant of Bartok and Mao by Kevan Davis.

name: Minibluff
notes: A Cucumber variant incorporating Backgammon-style doubling, contributed by Bernard Dulac. It can be played online at minibluff.com.

name: Minor Warfare
notes: A war variation by Joseph Smith in which battle outcomes are normally determined by suit.

name: Miser
notes: A reversed Spades variation in which players try to avoid taking tricks, contributed by Paul Edwards.

name: Mismatch
notes: A trick taking game for four players by David Parlett, in which the aim is to avoid taking tricks containing certain combinations of cards.

name: Missing Persons
notes: A game for two players by David Morrah, in which each tries to guess the identity of a card selected by the other.

name: Mississippi Gonorrhea
notes: A two-card high-low split pot draw poker variant by Robert Dier.

name: Mitch
notes: A variation of Mitch Gunzler's game Revolution, described by Mark Banilower and Patrick Phair.

name: Mixed Up Masters
notes: A variation of Phase 10 (Masters Edition) contributed by Keith Morris.

name: Mod 13
notes: A shedding game based on modular arithmetic, by Damjan Vukcevic.

name: Mom's Bluff
notes: A war variation for 3 to 5 players, with an element of poker-like bluff, by David Lewis.

name: Monastery
notes: A Contract Rummy variation for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard.

name: Montana Domino Rummy
notes: A game by Robert Kalin based on (Chinese Classical) Mah Jong adapted to be played with Western dominoes,  previously known as Four Pack and before that as Stonehenge.

name: More or Less
notes: A seven-card stud lowball poker variant by Les Stanwood

name: Mortal Swords
