notes: A sword fighting card game for 2 - 4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection.

name: Mose
notes: A rummy game with a varying wild card, in which cards can be laid down out of turn, contributed by Kendall Anderson.

name: Motown
notes: A seven-card stud poker variant by Patrick Koestler

name: Mountain
notes: A poker game by Charles Pierce in which players must fold if they cannot beat the mountain hand.

name: Multiple 9
notes: A game in which players try to get rid of their cards by discarding them is groups adding up to multiples of nine.

name: Multiple Card Brag
notes: A collection of partition games based on Brag hands, contributed by David and Andrew Horwell.

name: Multiple of Twelve
notes: A two-player game of rapid calculation, created by Jack Boettcher.

name: Murder
notes: A variation on Suicide by Jeffrey Hope.

name: Murder with the 2's
notes: A 7-card Stud Poker variant from Arthur Buderick in which 2's are wild and a player who is dealt a 2 or a pair face up must match the pot or fold.

name: Mutual of Omaha
notes: A poker variation contributed by Dennis Verbeek.

name: Mystery Wheelbarrow
notes: A poker variation by Richard Peluso and Jason McCrone in which players take turns to trade a card with a central layout.

name: Nags
notes: A game loosely based on Stops and Horse Racing, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Najami
notes: A mixture of Japanese Napoleon and Michigan, contributed by Vincent Pressicaud.

name: Naked Gibbon
notes: A game for 2-6 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. Cards may be played face down and can then be challenged. The winner of the challenge gets a doubt bonus while the loser's cards are exposed.

name: Nameless
notes: A game loosely based on Euchre, designed to be played with the cards left over from a Euchre deck, contributed by Ben.

name: Napoleon's War
notes: A game based on War but requiring some strategy, by Ian Ricksecker.

name: NASDAQ
notes: A six-card poker variant by Les Stanwood in which each player auctions one card to the others, with a seven-card variant by Ed Stack in which each player auctions two cards.

name: Nash Whist
notes: A Solo Whist variant with additional bids, by David Crossley. This is basically a four-player game, but a three-player version is also offered, and up to six people can take part if one or two sit out in rotation.

name: Nationhood
notes: A rummy variant for two players by Matthew Shields, where negotiation and bluff are elements of play.

name: Need a Fourth?
notes: A three-player Bridge variation by Larry Levy.

name: Nestors
notes: An unusual trick-taking game invented by Ali Safaaei. There are four players in fixed partnerships but each trick consists of only three cards, and the player who did not play to each trick leads to the next.

name: Network
notes: A game from the Domino Plaza website in which the aim is to score by completing closed rings of tiles.

name: New York New York
notes: A 7-card stud high low poker variation with selection of up cards, invented by Ellen Czeh and contributed by Dave Kinney.

name: Nexus
notes: A two-player trick-taking card game in two rounds by Curtis Parks.

name: Nil
notes: A game by Florent Barraco in which the object is to win no tricks at all or every trick.

name: Nimby
notes: A game inspired by Euchre, with some elements of Sheepshead, contributed by David Schulman.

name: Nineteen
notes: A cribbage variation by Debber40s

name: Ninety-nine Paranoia
notes: A variation of the adding game 99 by Graeme Frost.

name: Ninja
notes: A Shithead variation by Richard Garfield, in which jacks are difficult to beat.

name: No Man's Land
notes: A Solitaire Game of Sniping in World War I, by Walter O’Hara

name: No Peek High-Low
notes: A split pot variant of No Peek Poker by George Johnson.

name: No Regrets
notes: A Cribbage variant in which the starter card is turned up before discarding to the crib.

name: Nobility
notes: A novel type of combat game for three players, with elements of rummy, in which players can capture opponents' melds in battle. Contributed by Matthew Shields.

name: Norte
notes: A Shithead variant contributed by Adrian Murillo.

name: Novatarok
notes: A simplified tarot game for 2, 3 or 4 players by John Wright.

name: Number 9 Train
notes: A Train variant by Steve Shafer, using a double 9 domino set.

name: Nusicle
notes: A game based on Crazy Eights (Switch) but with multiple discard piles, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Nyuri
notes: A game by Malik Kadir in which players collect cards by using high cards to steal lower cards of the same suit from other players.

name: Ocean's Eleven
notes: An ingenious two-player game by Eliott Adkins in which each player has a supply of 52 cards drawn one at a time and the object is to win the best of 11 poker hands.

name: Odds
notes: A game for three or more players by Jacob Soener in which players aim to collect the best sets and sequences of odd cards by drawing, discarding and trading.

name: Odds and Ends
notes: A community card poker variant by Chris Gaskill

name: Off-Road Stud
notes: A stud poker variant in which a player's upcards are chosen from a communal 4x4 layout, contributed by Alan Kross-Vinson.

name: Oh Shit
notes: An Omaha Poker variant by Britt Martin.

name: Okinawa
notes: A Back Alley Bridge variant by Schumacher and Kottinger.

name: One Card
notes: A Korean / Philippine game of the Eights family, by Sev Arguelles.

name: One Card
notes: A trick-taking game for 2 to 4 players using a 25-card pack, by Alex Ruhsenberger.

name: One Left
notes: A Crazy Eights variant for two players, by Justin Huneke.

name: One Man's Trash
notes: A game for 2-5 players by Johann Tutor, unrelated to the poker variant with the same name. To win, a player must empty their hand by playing four of a kind to a trash pile.

name: One Man's Trash
notes: A poker variant by Andy Drew.

name: One Player Ninety-Nine
notes: A solitaire version of the adding game ninety-nine, contributed by Corey Dixon.

name: One-Minute Solitaire
notes: A simple solitaire against the clock, by Robert Gauss.

name: Oneonta Whist
notes: A trick taking game by Richard Hutnik, which can be played as a solitaire or by two or more players. The bidding is somewhat reminiscent of Spades, except that the bidder can choose a trump suit.

name: Open Whist
notes: A Whist-based game for 2 or 3 players by Sid Sackson, first published in GAMES magazine in March 1985. All the cards are open and arranged in columns; only the card on top of each column is available to play.

name: Opetong
notes: A quick and simple set collecting card game for 2 or 3 players, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Ops
notes: A two-player game with open cards by Bogart Salzberg, in which players swap pairs of cards to achieve an array satisfying certain arithmetical rules.

name: Oracle
notes: An original game by Peter Higgins. One player, the Oracle, holds a secret hand of cards and the other players try to win these cards by guessing their rank; when an Oracle's last card is taken, the player taking it becomes Oracle.

name: Orgy
notes: A four-player game by Andrew S Fischer, in which the aim is to collect picture cards in tricks.

name: Ottawa
notes: A matching game by Jorge Mata: players try to get rid of their cards by discarding them in ascending and descending runs and sets of equal cards.

name: Ouch
notes: An Oh Hell! variant from Brunswick, Maine in which each player discards 2 cards before the bidding, contributed by Skip Hansen.

name: Over Under
notes: A casino banking game by Jason Kobal in which a player places an ante to see one card and can then bet on having a total of more than 23 or less than 18 after being dealt two more cards. There are also fixed odds bonus bets on totals over 26 or under 13.

name: Padan
notes: A two player trick-taking game by Dan Vetter, in which each player has four hands of cards and chooses in what order to play them.

name: Pain
notes: A violent variation of War, contributed by Clay Brandenburgh.

name: Pairs
notes: A simple solitaire game by Alan Gilfoy.

name: Palace of %$#&
notes: A variation of Shithead (also known as Palace), contributed by Bret Caron.

name: Palace Poker
notes: A complex poker variant, contributed by Scott Henneman, in which players can bet head to head against another player, the winner taking the loser's upcards.

name: Palindrome
notes: A two-player game by Russ Schneider, in which cards are played to a layout with the object of forming symmetrical sets (palindromes).

name: Pancakes
notes: A game for up to 5 players by Johann Tutor in which the aim is to get rid of the cards from your hand by 'cooking' then on an array of stacks calles the 'griddle' and if possible serving cooked sets of 4 of a kind as pancakes.

name: Paperless Spades
notes: A game based on Spades, in which scores are kept using low cards, as in Euchre, invented by Hugh Aguilar.

name: Parcellus
notes: A stops game for three players by Matthew Shields.

name: Partnership Blackout
notes: A 4-player game by Scott Mayes combining elements of Blackout (Oh Hell) and Back Alley Bridge.

name: Pass and Out
notes: A Block Domino game by Andy Lewicki in which a player who passes has to drop out, and the player who forced them out scores for their unplayed tiles.

name: Pass Cribbage
notes: A Cribbage Variant for 3, 4 or 6 players by Jim Brennan in which players pass a card before discarding to the crib.

name: Pass-Pass
notes: A domino game for four players by Stephane Viallet.

name: Pass'Em
notes: A Hold'Em Poker variation with passed cards, by Harvey Fish.

name: Payroll
notes: A betting game with cards and dice by Manny Cruz, in which the player with the highest pair wins.

name: Peaks and Pits
notes: A domino game by Adrian Morgan in which players aim to make "slopes" - playing tiles so that the numbers progress either upwards or downwards - changes of direction are penalised.

name: Peatwit
notes: A plain-trick game with bidding, in which all the twos, threes and fours are trumps, but can only trump suits other than their own. Contributed by Paul Dunham.

name: Peek and Run
notes: An educational game by Charles Magri in which players try to claim four cells in a row on a 6x6 game board, where each cell corresponds to the product of the numbers on top of the two discard piles.

name: Penchant
notes: A two-player trick, meld and draw game originally published by “Jack Sharpe” (John Smith McTear) in 1893, and described by Jonathan Kandell with some suggested variants. It uses a 32-card pack and has a similar mechanism to Bezique or Marjolet, but with different melding and scoring possibilities.

name: Penguin Patience
notes: A solitaire game by David Parlett.

name: Pentyrch
notes: A game for four or two players by Mal Jones in which a card layout is used as a playing board on which other cards are moved.

name: People's Democratic Dictatorship
notes: A Mao variation in which each player is responsible for one of the rules, invented by Joseph Graly and contributed by his brother Marcus.

name: Perfect 10
notes: An Old Maid variant with a winner instead of a loser, by Terry Ann Womack.

name: Perfect Information Cribbage
notes: A Cribbage variant by Lucas Chojnowski.

name: Perico
notes: A draw and discard game by Steven Metzger in which the aim is to collect a good poker hand and then end the play by knocking.

name: Personal Uno
notes: Uno variant by se-no-fee-uh in which each winner adds a rule.

name: Phalanx
notes: A game for 2 or more players by Stefan Farias, related to War, but more strategic: players can choose how to deploy their cards in a battle taking place across three zones.

name: Phase 10 - alternative Phases
notes: A Phase 10 variant by Armanda Carvelli.

name: Phase 10 + 10
notes: An extended form of the commercial game Phase 10 with 10 extra phases, contributed by Justin Huneke

name: Phoenix Burn
notes: A showdown game between three-card hands, contributed by Tim Sharkey and Bob Conlon.

name: Pi
notes: An automatic game for 2-6 players by Paul Wright, based on the digits of the decimal expansion of pi.

name: Pick Your Crib
notes: A cribbage variation by Bill in which part of the crib is selected at random from the opponent's hand.

name: Pick-Up
notes: A fishing game contributed by Justin Lake.

name: Pickle
notes: A point-trick game with bidding for 2-5 players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. The bids are for tricks, but players score additional points for valuable cards taken in tricks, using a point schedule reminiscent of Pitch or Pedro.

name: Pickle
notes: A variant of 22 (the North American Cucumber game) by Dean Jensen in which the 3, 5 and jokers are top cards. On the Pickle page click the hand of cards to access the rulebook.

name: Pidro for three players
notes: A three-player version of the Ostrobothnian game Pidro devised by Carl Stenholm and Niklas Indola.

name: Piles
notes: A four-player card game by Fabbio Pozzi in which each team tries to capture cards of the other team's colour by playing cards to a central layout.

name: Piles
notes: A shared card high/low split pot poker game by George Johnson.

name: Pimps & Hoes
notes: A simple game by Joe V. & Raymond C., in which each player selects the best scoring five cards from the cards they are given.

name: Pinnacle
notes: Unrelated to Pinnacolo, Pinaculo or Pinochle, this game by Kevin Anglin uses rummy-like combinmations with a game mechanism similar to shared card poker.

name: Pirate Uno
notes: An Uno variation by Kyle.

name: Platinum Fish
notes: A Go Fish variant by Dom Bruno.

name: Plonk
notes: A four-player partnership game by David Parlett, in which the object is to win tricks containing cards of different suits from the card that was led.

name: Poe Crumb
notes: A draw and discard game based on Poker combinations, by Jared McComb.

name: Pokefish
notes: A game similar to Go Fish, in which the object is to collect certain poker combinations, contributed by Taryn and Kristal.

name: Poker Challenge
notes: A non-gambling card game based on poker hands by Jerry Flugaur.

name: Poker Euchre
notes: A trick-taking game for 2-12 players based on Euchre but played with a full 52-card deck, optionally with Jokers, and with Poker-like betting before the play, contributed by Joseph Allingham.

name: Poker Roulette
notes: A game of chance by Ross Dubery, in which cards are collected by a matching process and then compared as poker hands.

name: Poker Uno
notes: This game by Jason Anubis is played with standard cards so counts as an Eights variant despite its name. Poker-like combinations as well as single cards can be played.

name: Poker War
notes: A War variant by Mark Perkins, in which cards are played seven at a time rather than singly, and compared as poker hands.

name: Pokex
notes: An ingenious trick taking game, in which the winning of tricks is based on poker hands, contributed by Gabriel Schwartz.

name: Polt to Tzar
notes: A trick taking game for 5-7 players, with social status, contributed by Guyon Roche.

name: Ponsi
notes: A poker variant from Arthur Buderick in which players must pay increasing amounts to see each of the five shared cards.

name: Portraits
notes: A solitaire card game by James Kyle in which number cards are used to purchase picture cards from the market.

name: Possession
notes: An interesting rummy-like game by Guy Quang Tran, in which melds can be stolen from your opponent.

name: Pot Black
notes: A trick-taking game for 4 or 3 players by Rob Rutherford in which the black tens are penalty cards.

name: Potomac Blackout
notes: A variation of Oh Hell! in which the highest bidder chooses trumps after everyone has bid, described by Wei-Hwa Huang.

name: Pottle
notes: An exact bidding game by Joan Milliken in which only the highest successful bidder wins.

name: President Variations
notes: Variations of the popular game President, contributed by Colin Nielsen and Martin Hulsman.

name: Prime
notes: An adding game for 2-4 players by Jer Gallagher, in which each card played must make a prime total.

name: Prisoner of War
notes: A War variation by Ken Scherer

name: Prisoners
notes: The picture cards represent slaves and players use the pip cards ace to ten to bid for them. Contributed by Kate Thompson.

name: Privacy Poker
notes: A hybrid shared card / stud poker variant by Magnificence

name: Prize Dominoes
notes: A draw dominoes variant by Jared McComb.

name: Progression
notes: A strategic game for three players, who try to build a long ascending sequence of cards in each suit, invented by Wei-Hwa Huang.

name: Progressive Poker
notes: A game based on poker but without betting, contributed by Karlis.

name: Progressive War
notes: A War variation by Mark Stamp.

name: Psych
notes: A two-player Gops variation by Brad Chapman.

name: Psychic War
notes: A War variation by Emily Goodlife.

name: Psycho Poker
notes: A two player game based on poker hands, contributed by James Swerdfeger and Marc Reside.

name: Puck
notes: An interesting cross between Poker and War, invented by David Knight.

name: Punk
notes: A trick-taking game with simultaneous play in which only the player of lowest unique card in the trick scores its value, contributed by Mike Church.

name: Push It
notes: A War variant in which the aim is to get rid of cards, by Gary Philippy and Hayes Ruberti.

name: Puzzle
notes: A very simple competitive patience game by Matt Molver.

name: Pyramid
notes: A trick-taking game by Albinas Borisevicius. Players try to win the exact number of tricks that they bid, and each possible bid must be attempted a given number of times by each player during the game.

name: Pyramid (2)
notes: A Poker variation by Sq2yard.

name: Pys'ngtaut
notes: A Rummy variation with two discard piles by Stephen & Jill Rogers, in which sets of three cards are most valuable.

name: Q Squared Joe
notes: A set of related games contributed by James aka Q Squared. All are based on a common principle of which cards beat which. The basic game is similar to eights, but there are also two combat games: Q Squared Joe War and Q Squared Joe NG.

name: Quads
notes: A rapid game for 2-4 players by Brooke Nicole Shell in which the aim is to collect four of a kind.

name: Quantum
notes: An ingenious game involving trick-taking and collecting winning combinations of cards, created and thoroughly explained by Stephen Rogers and Jill Newman

name: Quantum Leap
notes: A game for 2 to 4 players by Mal Jones in which players score by adding cards to a 3×3 layout creating patterns according to various placing rules.

name: Quar
notes: Game in which players try to get rid of cards by playing them on "stations" in front of each player, matching number or suit. Complete with spoof historical introduction.

name: Queen, The
notes: A two-player game by James Yates in which players play cards to a central pile, scoring points for certain moves such as playing a three-card sequence or a Queen. His web site gives a very thorough introdcution to the game, with examples and discussion of strategy.

name: Queen's Dungeon
notes: A trick-taking game by Ken Blosser in which queens are the highest cards of their suits, carry a bonus and can be played to any trick.

name: Quick Seven™
notes: A casino game by Innovative Gaming, Inc. in which the aim is to make a total of 7 points, or as near as possible below it. Players are dealt cards one at a time, and are allowed one discard to create their best possible hand.

name: Quinto
notes: A trick-taking game with a hierarchy of trump suits and bonuses for tricks containing cards that add up to five. Quinto was invented by John Angelo Lewis (aka Professor Hoffmann, 1839-1919) around 1900, and is described on the above page by Howard Fosdick.

name: R-M-D Uno
notes: An Uno variation contributed by Ronda.

name: Rags and Riches
notes: A simple two-player draw and discard game by by Seth Garrison.

name: Rails
notes: A community card poker variant by George Weissenberger incorporating an extra combination - the "ticket".

name: Railway
notes: A game of luck, based on an Indian children's game, contributed by Anoop Sankar.

name: Rake
notes: A Poker variant conributed by Jeff Cross in which players complete their hands by drawing from a pool of face-up and face-down cards, and the Ace of spades automatically wins or loses

name: Rank
notes: A matching game, in which players dispose of their cards by playing a card equal or adjacent in rank to the previous play. Created by Corey Dixon.

name: RAW
notes: A War variation by Emma Dean, with the objective and the ranking of the cards reversed.

name: Real Poker
notes: A shared card high-low poker variant by Paul Bedrosian.

name: Realm of the Defenders
notes: A combat game using standard playing-cards, by Shawn Dumas.

name: Red and Black
notes: A rummy-like game by Kishor Gordhandas, in which players collect seven-card ascending and descending sequences.

name: Red Carpet
notes: A game by Mike Church in which pairs of cards are auctioned, and players try to buy cards to make up the best four-card combination.

name: Red Dragon
notes: A Palace / Shithead variation with all cards dealt and no draw pile, by Richard Glover.

name: Regicide
notes: A two-player trick and trump game by Robin Taylor, in which the trump suit and card ranking can be changed whenever a trick is won by the opponent of the player who led to it.

name: Regicide
notes: A co-operative combat game for up to 4 players, who work together to defeat 12 enemies turned up from the deck. Created by Paul Abrahams, Luke Badger and Andy Richdale.

name: Reoccurring Strange
notes: A trick taking game with two trump suits and two cards played by each player to each trick, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site. Like "Simple Strange" but stranger.

name: Repeat Poker
notes: A solitaire game based on poker hands, contributed by Pramod Mulay.

name: Replay Whist
notes: A whist-like game with bonuses for bidding the exact number of tricks taken, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Reveille
notes: A two-player version of Texas Forty-Two, invented by Ryan Barrett

name: Reverse Hearts
notes: A partnership Hearts variation contributed by Wendy Harvie, in which the object is to take hearts and the spade queen.

name: Reverse Shithead
notes: A Shithead variation by Andrew Duthie, which includes a reverse phase where beating the previous player's card is compulsory but disadvantageous.

name: Revolution
notes: A trick taking game, with unusual contraints on leading, following suit and determining trumps, contributed by sjhsniffen.

name: Revolution
notes: An original game in which players try to manage their cards, to play as many cards as possible of each suit in descending order - invented by Mitch Gunzler. See also the variation known as Mitch.

name: Rhine Rummy
notes: A manipulation rummy game based on Rummikub but played with regular cards, contributed by David Mallen.

name: Ri$ky Bu$ine$$
notes: A game by Jeffrey Mowery and Josh Mullins, in which players try to minimise their score by discarding cards to a range of piles and drawing replacements.

name: Riding Ramone
notes: A five-card stud lowball poker variant by Les Stanwood.

name: Right or Wrong
notes: A simple "higher or lower" card guessing game by William Malloy.

name: River Rat Rummy
notes: A rummy game with increasing hands, similar to 3-13 or Nickels, contributed by Greta Figel.

name: Rochester Poker
notes: A poker variant contributed by Mark Brown in which players are required to pass cards between rounds of betting.

name: Rock the Crib!
notes: A Cribbage variation by Bill in which the score for the crib is negative.

name: Rocket Pants
notes: A speed game of matching ranks, by Jacob Gohlke and friends.

name: Rocky
notes: A boxing simulation game in the form of a war variation, contibuted by Mackenzie Yeung.

name: Roller Coaster
notes: A shedding game by Kroc Camen in which sequences of cards are discarded.

name: Roller Derby
notes: A four-player partnership trick-taking game by Neal Lyons, in which the number of tricks to be taken is determined by rolling dice.

name: Romantiles
notes: A domino game by Bill Perkins: each player draws dominoes from a bag; any that cannot be played on the layout are displayed in front of the player in a 'mismatch row'. Also a variation Draworama.

name: Rook Pyramid
notes: A version of Pyramid Solitaire played with Rook cards, by Jeffrey Jacobs.

name: Rook Shanghai
notes: A version of Contract Rummy played with Rook cards, by William Robfogel

name: Ropebridge
notes: A two-player card game by Keith Parker in which the players race to cross a bridge by matching a row of cards.

name: Rose Mau
notes: A variation of Mao (Mau) with some similarities to Bartok, by Guy Srinivasan

name: Roundary
notes: A game by Bill Perkins, played with cards, dominoes, dice, chips and a cribbage board.

name: Rounds
notes: A point-trick game for two players in four rounds with changing trumps, contributed by David Schulman.

name: Roy
notes: A Crazy Eights variation invented by Roy Fuller, modified by Spike Walker and described by Lee Coursey.

name: Royal Ace-Assin
notes: A two player game by Thomas Gale: each player owns the three court cards of one suit, and supports each using numeral cards of the same suit. Based on partial information about the opponent's support, each player assassinates two of the opponent's courts, and the winner is the player whose surviving court card is better supported.

name: Royal Assassin
notes: A solitaire game by Mark Brown, whose object is to kill off court cards and retain your throne.

name: Royal Hold'em
notes: Texas Hold'em Poker with a 20-card pack.

name: Royal Lines
notes: A game for 2-6 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. Using number cards from their hand players bid for picture cards and try to build a high scoring collection.

name: Royal Mastheads
notes: A trick taking game for four players, in which extra points are scored for winning certain cards. Contributed by R. Kieva.

name: Royal Orgy
notes: A Tarock / Pinochle hybrid, contributed by Wayne Michael Shirk.

name: Royal Porcio
notes: Mark Moran's  four-player trick-taking game with bidding, in which one card per trick is recycled into a player's hand.

name: Royal Spades
notes: A two-player spades game using a 28-card or 30-card pack, by William Chamberlin.

name: Royals
notes: A fairly elaborate two-player game by Devin Carroll, in which cards won in tricks are used to form rummy-like melds. Here are the rules of Royals as a PDF, and also rules for a four-player partnership version Alliance Royals.

name: Rubber Band Cribbage
notes: A cribbage variation by Adam Fitzhugh in which games must be won by a margin of 10 points or less.

name: Ruby Run
notes: A shared card poker variant by H. G. Weissenberger in which sequences of three or more cards of the same colour beat normal poker hands.

name: Rugby League
notes: A two-player game by Joe Foxon.

name: Rush
notes: A two-player positional game by Kymani, using two 52-card packs.

name: Russian Roulette
notes: A community card poker variant by Patrick St-Louis.

name: Sabacc
notes: History, interpretations and reconstructions of the Star Wars card game by John Boucher and others.

name: Sakaali
notes: A four-player card game by Tuomas Korppi in which partners try to co-operate in discarding cards while keeping sets.

name: Sambola
notes: A hybrid of Samba and the New Zealand Canasta variant Jonola, devised by David Mallen.

name: Same Difference
notes: An original two-player game by Michael Levin and Tom Vonderharr, in which each card played must match the difference between two adjacent cards in the layout, and the objective is to block your opponent (the first player unable to play is the loser).

name: Same'Em
notes: A Hold'Em Poker variation by JDulius.

name: San Mateo Canasta
notes: A Canasta variation created by John Bejarano.

name: Savannah
notes: A card and dice game for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. Players build up shared foundation piles and try to exhaust their reserve and discard piles.

name: Scatterbrain
notes: A draw and discard game by Rob Dufour in which players try to form runs, but also to remember the other players' cards.

name: Scoundrel
notes: A card and dice game for 2 players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard. Players build columns of cards and wipe out the opponent's columns.

name: Scramble War
notes: A War variation in which both players draw cards from a common pile.

name: Screwin' Herman
notes: A poker variant by Ian Blessing

name: Scribbage
notes: A game based on Cribbage for any number of players, invented by the late Leonard Hadden.

name: Scum of the Earth
notes: A President variation inspired by the WotC games The Great Dalmuti and Dilbert Corporate Shuffle, contributed by Ryan McGuire.

name: Sedanto
notes: A draw and discard game by Owen Byer in which players keep their cards in four columns, trying to place cards of a single rank in each column.

name: Sequence Gin
notes: A Gin Rummy variant by Howard Fosdick with runs only (no sets).

name: Sequitur
notes: A game by George Hottensen in which players collect threes of a kind by drawing from and discarding to a layout, and then try to guess the identity of two face down cards.

name: Serpent
notes: A 2-player card game from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which cards are played in a serpent pattern; one player tries to connect pairs and runs, while the other tries to stop him.

name: Set Variants
notes: Tom Magliery's collection of variations of the commercial game Set.

name: Seven and What Makes It
notes: A variation of 7 card stud poker with up to 7 wild cards, contributed by Dan Mathe.

name: Seven Card Combo
notes: A game by Stephen McVerry in which by passing cards, players try to build a seven card hand in which all cards belong to combinations.

name: Seven Card Nopeek
notes: As in War, players flip their cards from a face-down hand. Each player must beat the previous player's card or combination or be knocked out. Contributed by Christian Mendoza.

name: Seven Card Open Draw
notes: A Draw Poker variant with open discards, by Bruce Leban.

name: Seven Card Rummy 3000
notes: A family rummy variant by Steve Bradbury.

name: Seven Spades
notes: A simple and original bluffing game by Johan Wästlund; the winner is the first player to collect seven spades, or more often the winner of a challenge when a bluff is suspected.

name: Seven Up
notes: A game by Adam, in which the winner is first player who turns up a card of each rank from ace up to seven.

name: Sevens and Eights
notes: A cribbage variation by Debber40s

name: Sevens and Eights
notes: A Crazy Eights variant contributed by Jonny Groves

name: Seventeen
notes: A point-trick game in which you are rewarded for points up to 17 but penalised for any excess points you take, contributed by 'Weirdguy38'.

name: Sex in the Middle East
notes: A Poker variant by Ian Blessing

name: Shaftmount
notes: A game for 2-4 players by Igor Alba, in which players try to avoid penalty points for closing sequences.

name: Shamus
notes: A co-operative two-player game with elements of 500 Rummy and Uno, contributed by Erin McGilvray.

name: Shanghai
notes: A domino and dice game for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which chains of dominos are constructed such that the ends match dice rolls.

name: Shark Attack
notes: A four-player game in three rounds by Seth Williams, in which the cards you play must be neither too high nor too low.

name: Sharp Nullo
notes: A four-player partnership game by Hans Peter Albach in which players bid on open cards and play to avoid taking tricks.

name: Shmath
notes: A two-player game by Abbi Pittman in which players take turns to capture sets of three cards which satisfy an arithmetic equation.

name: Shogun
notes: A combat game for 2-4 players using a 52-card deck, contributed by Daniel Villanueva.

name: Shop Solitaire
notes: A solitaire game by Gabriel Arthur Petrie.

name: Short Bismarck
notes: A 43-card variation of Bismarck, by Frank Dobbs.

name: Shotgun Cribbage
notes: Cribbage without the crib, contributed by Dave and Jeff.

name: Showcase
notes: A two-player game loosely based on German Whist, invented and contributed by Charles Magri. Every suit trumps every other, and only tricks won by trumping are of value.

name: Shrine
notes: A combat game by Julian "Legend" Jimenez using the standard 52-card deck plus an optional joker

name: Shuffle Game
notes: A simple game that is also a way to shuffle a deck of cards, contributed by Sarah Shimazaki.

name: Simple Rummy
notes: A collection of Rummy games by John Davidson, played with a 52-card pack plus a selection of various extra cards including some wild cards, some that cannot be melded and some with a specific point count.

name: Simple Strange
notes: A trick taking game with two trump suits and two cards played by each player to each trick, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Sinful Gibbon
notes: A game (formerly known as Heartless Gibbon) for 3-6 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. Cards are played face down with a promise of what they are and may be challenged. The loser of a challenge collects the play pile which may score penalty points for 'deadly sins'.

name: Six Card Draw
notes: A version of draw poker using six-card hands, by Jeff Cross. Michael Keller has provided an analysis of the probabilities of hands.

name: Six Card Open Draw
notes: A Draw Poker variant with open discards, by Bruce Leban.

name: Six Stacks
notes: A game by Jacob Kroll in which players add cards to a solitaire-like layout. A player who is unable to play gets a "strike", and on the third strike is eliminated.

name: Skarney
notes: A Contract Rummy game with joker melds and no discard pile, invented by John Scarne and described by Howard Fosdick.

name: Skirmish
notes: A game by Kevin Anglin with some similarities to Rummy. The extra combinations and the possibility of "dropping" cards speed up the game and increase the opportunities for bluffing strategies.

name: Skrap
notes: A game for 2-5 players by by Craig Bednar in which players compete using two-card "bots" made up of a black weapon card and a red armour card.

name: Skuck
notes: An exact bidding game for two players, by Ron and Sue Craig.

name: Skyscraper
notes: A domino game for 2-3 players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which dominoes are stacked up to build a skyscraper. If you can't legally build on the skyscraper, you lose.

name: Skyscraper Elevator
notes: A shared card poker game by Charles Pierce.

name: Slam-aha
notes: An Omaha Poker variant by Britt Martin.

name: Slap
notes: A variation of Slapjack with extra slapping, contributed by Justin Huneke.

name: Slap Off
notes: A game by Jonathan Trabing based on Egyptian Ratscrew and Slapjack, incorporating sexual language which some may find offensive. Here is a link to the rules.

name: Sleazy
notes: A draw and discard game for 2 or 4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. Players try to form pairs and sets of 4 equal cards on the table.

name: Sleepless
notes: A game using cards and poker dice, by John Mitchell. There are several objectives: to match cards to dice, to have the best combination of cards, and to win the most tricks.

name: Slippery Slope
notes: A three-player exact trick taking game with unusual card ranking rules, by Brien Patterson and Vicki Jackson.

name: Sloppy Seconds
notes: A trick taking game by Peter Schell, in which the aim is to take the second highest number of points in each suit, and trumps is the second suit to be 'broken' (played on a lead of a different suit).

name: Slovak Double Barrel
notes: A rapid fixed stake poker game by Ilya Bugreyev.

name: Slovenian Uno
notes: An Uno variation for advanced players by Jure Leskovec.

name: Smack My Bitch Up
notes: A poker variant, based on Follow the Queen, contributed by Andy "Sprocket" Noreen

name: Smith Uno
notes: An UNO variation contributed by Bryan Brady.

name: Smokestack
notes: Playing simultaneously, players try to collect various kinds of four-card sets by swapping cards from their hand with face-up cards.

name: Snag
notes: A 2-player trick-taking card game from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which players have their own hands, plus a shared board. Players try to capture many cards of a single suit.

name: Sneak
notes: A game of bluff for 2 to 7 players, by David Parlett. Players can lead one or more cards face down, hoping to win if no one challenges by trying to play a higher card or combination.

name: Sneaky Cards
notes: A social game using a special pack of cards which can be downloaded free (under a Creative Commons license) and printed at home. The aim is, over a period of days, to get rid of your cards, mainly by giving them to other people, following the instructions printed on them.

name: Snitch
notes: A rather unusual fishing game, with some similarity to the Iranian game Gharat, contributed by Geoff Klassen.

name: Social Climbing
notes: A game for 2-6 players by Ben Finn in which the aim is to build columns of equal or adjacent cards, if possible containing court cards (aristocrats), and bank them when topped with a 3, 6 or 9.

name: Solitaire Bridge
notes: A card game for one player based on Contract Bridge, developed by Stephen Rogers.

name: Solitaire Uno
notes: An UNO variation for one player, by Moonbeam.

name: Solitary Gin
notes: A Gin Rummy variant for one player by Susan Plank.

name: Solo Nus
notes: A one-player version of the Crazy Eights variant Nusicle, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Sottomondo Cards
notes: This game by Cristiano Leoni, whose name means "underworld cards" is a free collectible card game for two to six players. The special cards are provided on the website as a PDF to be printed and cut out.

name: Soureh
notes: A draw and discard game by Lior Chaga in which players replace cards in their own or their opponents' 8-card layouts with the aim of being the first to reach a configuration known as 'Soureh'.

name: Southern Deuce Hold'em
notes: A Texas Hold'em Poker variation by Justin Huneke: there are only four community cards, but each player receives a different wild deuce as a third card at the end.

name: Space War, The
notes: A space-themed combat game for two players by Jim Westergren. The website provides rules, images from which the custom cards can be printed at home, tutorial videos and a free online version of the game. There is a core set of cards and two extensions.

name: Spades
notes: A Seven Card Stud Poker variant from Arthur Buderick's collection in which players must pay the pot for wild spades.

name: Spank!
notes: One of Noby and Rusty's Games. Players score by building sequences of three or more consecutive cards.

name: Sparts
notes: Sparts is a cross between Spades and Hearts. Spartsel adds some features of Oh Hell! as well. Contributed by Doug Meyer.

name: Speahx
notes: A game that combines the mechanism of Shithead with the playing rules of Eights.

name: Speed Cribbage
notes: Cribbage variation in which each player gets an extra crib, by T Hodge.

name: Speed Uno
notes: An UNO variation contributed by David Swart, plus alternative rules by David Rutter.

name: Speed War
notes: A War variation contributed by Eric Longley.

name: Speedo Cribbage
notes: A cribbage variation with a different way of discarding to the crib, by Maria Thomas.

name: Spellevate
notes: A climbing game using alphabet tiles, contributed by Jared McComb.

name: Spidge
notes: This game for 3 players, contributed by Chris Young, takes from Bridge the idea that one player (in this case the dealer) controls a dummy hand, and from Spades the permanent spade trump suit and the scores for Nils. A variation is given with jokers as high trumps which cancel if played to the same trick.

name: Spiralling Shape
notes: A solitaire card game by Jesse Fuchs in which you try turn a grid of 16 cards to your colour (red or black) by means of a series of "conversions" of cards by adjacent cards, carried out in spiral sequence.

name: Splatoids
notes: A Shithead variation by Ian Marson.

name: Split
notes: A draw and discard game in which you try to build two three card hands whose point value is equal and odd. Created by Matt Singer, Christian Dietrich and Trevor Binney

name: Split
notes: A variation of Go Fish in which sets of only three cards are collected, contributed by Jonathan Touchette.

name: Splunk
notes: A combination of BS, 21 and Snap, contributed by John P Lawrence.

name: Spokane Open Wild
notes: A poker variant by Dave DeLine - akin to a stud game but players have a choice of cards to add to their hand at each stage.

name: Spooneye
notes: A two-player game created by Jesse Fuchs in which each player tries to build "masts" of 21 points to capture the opponent's masts.

name: Spots
notes: A poker variant in which the pot is split three ways, contributed by Scott Pangle.

name: Spy vs Spy
notes: A simultaneous play game by Jeff Dorak, in which players try to unload their cards onto up to six discard piles.

name: Squaressi Kings
notes: A variation of Kings Corners, contributed by Bill Perkins. See also the variations Squaressi Queens, Squaressi Jacks, Squaressi Aces and Squaressi.

name: Stalin
notes: A Crazy Eights variant with two play piles by Chris Carter.

name: Stand Off
notes: A two-player game by C. Scott Davis and Mark Davis, in which players try to collect five cards of one suit by exchanging cards with the stock and with each other.

name: Stanley Cup Run
notes: RetroDawg's simulation of an NHL hockey season, using playing-cards.

name: Statistics
notes: A game for 2 to 4 players by Jesse Eldred in which cards are played to a pile and captured by Aces.

name: Steeplechase Rook
notes: An interesting but lengthy variation of 4-player call-partner Rook for dedicated players, invented at lifeFORCE and contributed by Luke Bunger.

name: Stop, Drop and Roll
notes: A community card poker variant by George Weissenberger.

name: Straights
notes: A poker-like game by Wayne Ozarko in which only sequences of consecutive cards have a value.

name: Stratego
notes: An adaptation of the board game Stratego (or l'Attaque) using two double 6 domino sets.

name: Strato-Sphere
notes: A war game played with cards, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Streets and Avenues
notes: A new domino game by Stephen and Kenneth Kokoska. Tiles are played in a street grid pattern, the aim being to complete enclosed blocks.

name: Strike!
notes: A game for three or four players, simulating ten-pin bowling, contributed by James Thomas.

name: Strobe
notes: A community card poker variant by George Weissenberger.

name: Stubs & Spoils
notes: A four-player trick-taking game by Mark Moran in which one card per trick is recycled into a player's hand.

name: Stud-Jack
notes: A 7-card stud poker variation incorporating an element of blackjack, invented by Ken McKenzie and contributed by Dave Kinney.

name: Suaro
notes: A two-player plain-trick game with Bridge-like bidding, invented by Jason Short and Matt Bourland.

name: Subtraction War
notes: A War variation by Jesse Weinstein and Nancy Fuller in which cards are played two at a time and subtracted.

name: Suicide
notes: A money game with no skill at all, invented by Joakim Malmquist.

name: Suicide King
notes: A game of pure luck, by Paintball1688, in which the player who draws the K is eliminated from the game.

name: Suicide Swiss Hold'em
notes: Similar to Xavier Petit's Swiss Hold'em, but with the King of Hearts wild.

name: Suit High
notes: A war variation by Jason Berger.

name: Suitmatch
notes: A game by Adrian Morgan, in which you try to collect an equal number of cards of each suit by swapping cards with your neighbour.

name: Suits
notes: A trick taking game by Aaron Barnhart in which each player has a complete suit, but only has access to a few cards at a time. Playable as a solitaire game against three dummy players or as a real four-player game.

name: Suits
notes: A simple race to sort the cards into suits, by Tony Powell and Brian Clark

name: Suits
notes: A negative point-trick game loosely based on Hearts, by Brad Tonkes.

name: Suits Duel
notes: A combat card game for two players by Nicholas Fletcher.

name: Suits Me
notes: A game for 2-6 players by Seth Williams in which, by trading, discarding and drawing, the players try to collect seven cards of the same suit.

name: Suns to Moons
notes: An addition and subtraction game by Paul Hines.

name: Super Crazy Eights For Two
notes: A two handed adaptation of the traditional game Crazy Eights by Donald G Keller and Michael Keller.

name: Super Dominoes
notes: A block domino game for a [15-15] set by David Galt, in which tiles of the 13, 14 and 15 suits have special effects when played.

name: Super Hearts
notes: A version of Hearts with improved scoring to make the game play more demanding. Contributed by Jerry Schwartz.

name: Super Nus
notes: A "real-time" version of the Crazy Eights variant Nusicle, in which everyone plays as fast as possible without waiting for turns. From Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Super Pokeno Bonus
notes: A Pokeno variant by Jason Berger.

name: Super Screw Your Neighbour
notes: An Oh Hell! variant with extra top trumps, contributed by Murray Poole.

name: Super Wild Phase 10
notes: A variation of the Phase 10 Masters Edition by Jeff Presley with some slightly easier contracts and enhanced wild and skip cards.

name: Superjack: The Game
notes: A combat game for two players developed by Bryan Brodsky and Eric Hesson, similar to Magic The Gathering but played with two standard 40-card decks, one per player.

name: Superjoker
notes: A Shithead variation by Gaz and Elf.

name: Swiss Hold'em
notes: A Texas Hold'em Poker variant by Xavier Petit, in which players can pay to exchange their hole cards for new ones.

name: Switch
notes: Not the traditional eights game, but an original game by Crad Kilodney with a few (maybe coincidental) similarities. Rules are on this archive copy of the July 2002 page of his Dead Man Talking site.

name: Switch
notes: A poker variant by Brenton, in which players draw one card from their left-hand neighbour's hand.

name: Switched Up
notes: A simplified Eights game for two players, inspired by the commercial game Swap, contributed by by Justin Huneke.

name: SWOPS
notes: A two-player Gops variation by John H Conway.

name: Table
notes: An interesting and unusual game combining trick taking and formation of combinations, created in Colombia by Reynel Cuevas Mejia. When you win a trick you add its cards to your hand, and discard some cards; then all players replenish their hands to four cards. The aim is to form certain combinations in your hand, and it is also possible to win points by declaring and winning several consecutive tricks. There are two jokers, called the bono and the gadget, which have special effects that can benefit or disadvantage the holder.

name: Table Top Cribbage Solitaire
notes: A solitaire game for those who like to practise counting cribbage hands, by George Moore.

name: Tableau Cribbage
notes: A perfect information game based on Cribbage hands, by Andy Lewicki.

name: Taboo
notes: A fishing game based on Tablanette, by Graham Turner.

name: Take
notes: A rummy variation by Alan McCollough, in which players capture other players' melds when they add cards to them.

name: Takeover
notes: A simple battle game involving speed and dexterity, in which numeral cards are captured by picture cards (assassins) of the same suit. Authors: Kevin Saddi and Manuel Garcia

name: Tantra
notes: A variant of Contract Rummy in which the objective and wild card for each round are randomly selected using special cards, invented by W.J.Woolcock, Victoria, Australia in 1988, revised in 1991 but no longer commerically available.

name: Tapiola Hold'em
notes: A shared card poker variant from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection.

name: Tauko Hogni
notes: A Shithead variant invented while trekking the Nepalese Himalayas and contributed by Miguel Garvie.

name: Team Rook
notes: A Rook variation for six players in teams of three, by William Robfogel.

name: Team Uno
notes: A partnership version of Uno with exposed cards, by Wayne Shaw.

name: Tedesco Gin
notes: A Gin Rummy variant with round-the-corner sequences, contributed by Rick Pierro.

name: Telefunken Desordenata
notes: A contract rummy game based on Telefunken developed by Carla and Fernanda Basaure and contributed by Cindy Basaure.

name: Ten Card Rummy
notes: A Contract Rummy variant dating from the 1941 London Blitz, described by Matthew Pryor.

name: Ten-card Basketball
notes: A Golf variation by Brady Bunkelman.

name: Tennis
notes: An unusual trick-taking game in which the cards rank cyclically, and the cards you win in tricks form your hand for the next round. Invented by JC Ravage and Jimmy Kaplowitz.

name: Tennis
notes: A two-player trick-taking game with exact bidding, in which each player has two hands, 'forehand' and 'backhand'. Invented by Elliot Grant.

name: Texas Dozen
notes: A Texas Hold'em poker variant in the community cards are selected from a 5x5 layout, contributed by Alan Kross-Vinson.

name: Texas Reach Around
notes: A poker variation invented by Nick Henson; description contributed by Jeffrey Able.

name: Texas Tornado
notes: A Hold'em Poker variant by Chris Gaskill

name: That's It
notes: A rummy-like game using a [15-15] domino set, by David Galt.

name: The Bluffs
notes: A shared card hi-lo poker variant by David Migoya.

name: The Game Called 'The'
notes: A shared card poker game contributed by Thomas Yarbrough.

name: The Nine
notes: A simple two-player strategy game designed by Yusuf and Yaqub.

name: The Seven Pis
notes: A domino solitaire game by Chris Smyth

name: Thieving Stink
notes: A trick taking game by Steve Zdancewic, in which the winner of a trick can choose to lead to the next or change the trump suit.

name: Third Hand
notes: A point-based trick taking game for two players by Matthew Shields (inventor of Upper Hand), which combines elements of that game with a crib (or third hand) and a bidden contract with the discards significant as currency and as high rank. Revised, with strategy guide added.

name: Thirteen
notes: A simple two-player game by Alex Olesen in which players get rid of cards by playing a card one higher or one lower than the previous play.

name: Thirteens
notes: A trick-taking game by Bob Myers in which the main aim is to capture sets of cards that add up to 13.

name: Three Cut Cribbage
notes: A Cribbage variation by Cody Myers-Miller in which players can vote to reject the starter card.

name: Three Dozen
notes: An adaptation for Western dominoes of a Korean draw and discard domino game the aim is to make pairs.

name: Three Kings
notes: A fishing game in which capture by addition or subtraction is allowed, by Jimmy Kaplowitz and JC Ravage.

name: Three-Hole Poker
notes: A poker variation in which players use their own 3 cards plus two of the cards exposed by other players to make up their hand.

name: Three-Player Spades
notes: Two three-player single deck versions by Darrin Berkley.

name: Three-Player Spades with Two Decks
notes: A Spades variation by Paul Edwards.

name: Three-Two-One
notes: A poker variation invented by Treetop Collier

name: Throw-up Dominoes
notes: A game for 2-3 players by Alan Ackroyd, in which the playable dominoes are restricted by a throw of three dice.

name: Tien Len with Jokers
notes: A Tien Len variant by Bryon Pace.

name: Tiger Bridge
notes: A Bridge variant with restricted bidding and simplified scoring, contributed by Glenn Nicholls.

name: Tile Rummy
notes: A variation of Tile Rummy contributed by Vivian A. McGraw

name: Tinkle
notes: A Contract Rummy variant by Luke Baars.

name: Tips To The Fat One
notes: A two-player game with five pots by Alan Kross-Vinson in which players partition their cards into poker hands.

name: Toad
notes: A draw and discard game by Richard Smith in which players must achieve an exact point count of red and black cards to avoid losing a life.

name: Toby Dammit
notes: An Eights variant by Joseph D. Smith in which several cards of matching rank or suit can be played in one turn.

name: Tony '6 and 1' Brown
notes: A gambling game for two players, invented by Jonathan Robinson and Thomas Little.

name: Toss
notes: Variants of spades, hearts, euchre and other games designed to be played with an eight-suited deck.

name: Total War
notes: Doug Caspian-Kaufman's variation of War in which players have to announce whether they think they will win the trick.

name: Tournament of Queens
notes: Contributed by Roland M Reagan and Kelan Wieloch, this game uses a fortune-telling Tarot deck but is entirely unlike a tarot game. The premise is that the players are drag queens taking part in a beauty contest. They play cards representing their attributes, so as to please the panel of judges whose preferences are represented by an array of cards dealt at the start.

name: Towers
notes: A game of bridge building and demolition from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Towers and Bowers
notes: A Euchre variant for two players by Christopher Haviland in which the hand size reduces by one for each deal and the object is to win all the tricks.

name: Train
notes: A game by Zachary Franciscus in which players play simultaneously, trying to get rid of their cards by adding them to piles according to certain rules.

name: Train Wreck
notes: A seven card stud variation by Kevin Borror, in which certain pairs among a player's table cards give a bonus card of allow a card to be taken from another player.

name: Traitor
notes: A War variation by Connor Browne.

name: Treason
notes: A whist-like game for three players in which anyone taking a queen in a trick forfeits all tricks so far won. Created by Tom Retter.

name: Tredici
notes: A game for four players by Jordon Kalilich, in which the aim is to collect a complete suit of 13 cards.

name: Très
notes: One of Keith Stevens' new card games. A trick taking game for two players in which three cards are played to each trick: the leader plays the first and last cards and the other player plays second; turn to lead alternates.

name: Tri-Cap
notes: A game by Yoni Goldstein in which the center card is captured by a card adjacent in rank.

name: Triangle
notes: A three-player induction game by Patrick St-Louis, in which you try to state a fact about your own card seeing only the cards of the other players.

name: Trib
notes: A bridge-like trick taking game for two players, with positive and negative bids, from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site.

name: Trick Walls
notes: A kind of trick-taking game (formerly known as Civil War) from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. 2-6 players form two teams, red and black, and use the cards fom their hands to build 'city walls', aiming to have most of the face-up cards in their wall being of their own team's colour.

name: Tricks'N'Trumps
notes: An introductory trick-taking game for children, by Carol Phillips.

name: Trigami
notes: A three-player version of David Parlett's Bugami, in which each player independently decides which suit to avoid taking in tricks.

name: Triple Deck Solitaire
notes: Designed and contributed by Alan Gilfoy.

name: Trixter
notes: An Oh Hell! variant by Max Suchy.

name: Trolley Car
notes: A game by Rick Heli, in which players players get rid of their cards by playing them to a layout representing trolley lines.

name: Trump 7
notes: A game inspired by Sheepshead, with a joker added to the pack, contributed by David Schulman.

name: Trump Hearts
notes: A Hearts variation by Daniel Czech in which the trump suit changes for every trick.

name: Trumps
notes: A trick-taking game in which each player has their own trump suit, contributed by Stan J. Towianski.

name: Trunks
notes: A War variation by trance574.

name: Tunge
notes: A game from Andrew Brewood and Francis Irving's New Card Games site, in which players play groups of cards to a discard pile, aiming to get rid of their cards. Cards which match cards in the previous group force the following player to pick up.

name: Tweetjes
notes: A trick taking game in which some cards are worth positive points while others carry penalty points. Contributed by Remco Hartog.

name: Twelve
notes: A game for 3-6 players by Sam Levey and friends, also known as Jamaican Sniping, in which players win the pile by matching its top card or making a total of 12.

name: Twelve Man Combat
notes: Although this game, contributed by Jeffrey Cannon, has the layout of a combat game, "battles" are conducted by matching number or suit, as in eights games.

name: Twenty
notes: A skilful adding game for two players, invented by Alexander Farrugia. Players take turns to add cards to a tally pile, aiming either to make exactly 20 or to get as far beyond 20 as possible.

name: Twenty
notes: A skilful adding game for 2 players, also playable by 3 or 4, in which players take turns to play cards totalling each number from 1 to 20. Contributed by Brian Stovel.

name: Twist Solitaire
notes: A solitaire game by Bill Perkins.

name: Twisted Shithead
notes: An elaborate variation of Shithead, in which nearly all the cards have special effects. Game created by Galbraith/Lewis/Constance/Mabely (1993); description by Paul JaYmes (1997).

name: Two Away
notes: A self-working game by Katie Adams, in which cards are captured by turning a card that is not more than two away from the first card played.

name: Two Blind Bitches
notes: A Hearts variation for two players with two dummies, contributed by Blade2106.

name: Two Eleven
notes: An Omaha Poker variant by Bruce Paul.

name: Two Thirds
notes: A poker variant by Andrew Demkovich.

name: Two-Player Hearts
notes: A version of the classic game played with a reduced pack of 28 cards, by Jeffrey Hope.

name: Two-Player Spades
notes: A version by Darrin Berkley in which each player plays his or her own hand and one partly exposed dummy hand.

name: Two-Spit
notes: A five-card stud poker variant by David Migoya.

name: Two-Step
notes: A two-player domino game by Sam Robinson.

name: Two-Tray Tile Rummy
notes: A two-player manipulation tile rummy game by Dennis Norby in which each player plays two hands.

name: Twos
notes: A trick-taking game by Áron Csathó in which the aim is to take picture cards, but more importantly to catch twos from the other players. Catching twos is difficult because the twos do not have to follow suit, and can only be beaten by a previously played two or by the three of the same suit.

name: Twyst
notes: A four-player game by David Parlett, distantly related to Solo Whist, but with simultaneous bidding.

name: U-G-O
notes: A combat game for two or more players using one standard 52-card deck each, by Michael Daniel.

name: Unbreakable
notes: A combat game for two players by dylan - at each turn, each player selects two out of three 'weapon' cards whose sum is as close as possible to an attack card.

name: Uncle Bob's Left Nut
notes: A five card draw poker variant by Grey Doffin.

name: Uno from Hell
notes: An UNO variation, contributed by S D Rhodes.

name: Uno the Gathering
notes: Uno variation by Mark Brown, using standard cards with some Magic the Gathering cards added.

name: Uno with slapping, sliding and blank cards
notes: An Uno variation by Jonny Oakland

name: UNO: YS Duel Card Variation
notes: A combat game using UNO cards, by Jireh Orobia.

name: Unu
notes: A crazy eights variant by sjhsniffen.

name: Up-Down-Stop
notes: A domino solitaire game by Chris Smyth

name: Up-Down-Stop44
notes: A version of Up-Down-Stop for 2-4 players, by Chris Smyth

name: Upper Hand
notes: A point-based trick taking game by Matthew Shields, where players assume or barter for the "upper hand", where a hand can be strengthened and trumps and high rank can be nominated.

name: Upward
notes: An automatic game for two players where cards are played in upward sequence and the aim is to be the first player to run out of cards.

name: Usurp
notes: One of Noby and Rusty's Games. An unusual cross between trick-taking and Eights-type play. If you follow suit and beat the previous card, you score points; you also score points if you follow rank (usurp); otherwise you give away points. You can also try to bluff by playing your card face down.

name: Valentine Hearts
notes: A Hearts variation, with special rules for the Q and Q, by Nicholas Cheung.

name: Vancouver Stud
notes: A hybrid of Stud and Hold'em Poker by Torey Jones.

name: Vancy
notes: A shedding game by Joe Liang, in which you play a card one higher or lower than the previous play, or a set of cards that add up to the required amount.

name: Variable Trump Tute
notes: Mark Steere's variation of the Spanish game Tute, in which the trump suit changes each time a trump is played.

name: Waiting for Godot
notes: A poker variant by Andrew Foley.

name: Wall Street
notes: Not to be confused with the poker variant Wall Street, this is a simplified version of Scopa, invented by Dan Beebe.

name: Wamptu
notes: A War variation with bizarre card ranking, contibuted by Barton Scrange.

name: War of Kingdoms
notes: War variation by Eldad Yechiam in which players can rearrange the order of the cards they win.

name: Water Sharks
notes: A guessing game by Ashleigh Welko and Emily Furillo. Players try to guess whether cards in their hand are higher or lower than cards face down on the table.

name: Wee Madame
notes: A game of fast reactions by Nick Trupia. It is similar to Snap or Slapjack, and can be played as a drinking game.

name: Weeping Willow
notes: A poker variation in which players can trade cards with each other, contributed by Roger Shuman.

name: Wellsix
notes: A two-player game by Fabio Pozzi in which players try to complete a row or column of six cards of their own colour.

name: Welsh Warfare
notes: A GOPS-like game for four players, by Rhys Morgan.

name: Wheelers
notes: A guts game by Alan Kross-Vinson in which the object is to make straights.

name: Whiplash
notes: A four card draw and discard game by Colin Martin in which players try to collect the highest three or four of a kind.

name: Whiskey
notes: A three player trick taking game, with bids to win or to lose tricks, by Elliot Grant.

name: Who Da Baby Daddy Is
notes: A stud poker variation by Ten Ox, in which the last card dealt to each player is wild.

name: Who Dares Wins
notes: A variation of Suicide (in which players are eliminated if they turn over the Ace of Spades), by Aden Scott.

name: Whysteria
notes: An Oh Hell variant by Benn Finn in which players can bid in any order and anyone can lead to any trick.

name: Wichita
notes: A card and dice game for 2 or more players from the Rinkworks Pips collection by Samuel and Jacob H. Stoddard, in which cards are added and subtracted to match dice rolls.

name: Widow Jack
notes: A stud poker variant by Fran

name: Wife Beater
notes: A combat game with an unpleasant theme, contributed (but not invented) by David M.

name: Wild Speed
notes: A Speed variation with a wild card, by Nico Rodriguez.

name: Wildouble
notes: A draw domino game by Bill Perkins, which is won either by playing all of your dominoes or by playing a particular double, designated as the 'wild' double; also a variation Willynilly in which the double blank is 'wild'.

name: Wilson System
notes: A system of Hearts scoring, described by Dave Jordan.

name: Wind of Fortune
notes: A game (formerly called One Nation) for 2-4 players from Mikael Sauren's Koodikulma collection. Two teams battle to build two towers of picture cards (J, Q, K) of their colour and then place a joker on top to harness the Wind of Fortune.

name: Window
notes: A Switch (or Crazy Eights) variant by David Larby.

name: Wizard Duel
notes: A combat game for three or more players, contributed by Romain Tello.

name: Wizards Grimoire
notes: A combat game using Tarot cards, by Dokuga Kazu.

name: Woodstock
notes: A shared card poker variant by Ryan Plourde in which the cards on the board are chosen by the players.

name: Woolworth's Jackpot Penalty MJTF
notes: A seven card stud poker variant by Craig Roy.

name: World War III
notes: A complicated War variation for up to 6 players, by David Morrah.

name: Wraparound
notes: A poker variant with round the corner straights by George Weissenberger.

name: Wrestling
notes: A card simulation of a wrestling match, by Adam Lambert.

name: Wump Rummy
notes: A children's game - a simplified form of Scopa or Casino - by Kendall J. Redburn

name: Wyoming Cowboy
notes: A fairly elaborate combat game for three or four players using standard playing-cards, contributed by Kent McKay.

name: Xato
notes: A memory game by Áron Csathó.

name: Yacht
notes: A fairly simple trick-taking game with exact bidding, contributed by Drew Brokke.

name: Yonac
notes: A game with some similarity to Suicide but far more elaborate, contributed by Johann Tutor.

name: Yoshi
notes: A game by Don Taber, in which you try to collect poker combinations in a hand of 13 cards.

name: YouKnow
notes: UNO variation by Danny Bruggeling in which you can see other players' cards but not your own.

name: Young Hunter
notes: A trick taking game in which the aim is to capture jacks, contributed by Áron Csathó.

name: Zetema
notes: Howard Fosdick's description of this two-player game of drawing, discarding and combinations, using a 65-card pack formed by duplicating one suit of the standard 52-card pack. Zetema was published by the card maker Joseph Hunt in the 1870's and was probably invented by Walter Pelham, who worked there from 1871 to 1874.

name: Zigzag
notes: A three-player domino game with a novel trick-taking mechanism by Hans Peter Ahlbach.

name: Zoot
notes: A guts game by Alan Kross-Vinson in which the object is to have as few suits as possible.

name: 1 Zodiac
notes: A crazy eights variant by Trevor Cuthbertson.

name: 3 Chip Stack
notes: A betting game with 3-card hands, in which the aim is to win all the chips, by Jim Kuglics and Jamie Licari.

name: 3-13 Speed
notes: A rapid version of 3-13 Rummy for large groups, with simultaneous drawing and discarding, by Stan Stone.
A trick-taking card game for 3-5 players by Alex Raulli in which the object is to win tricks containing threes.

name: 5 Man Melee
notes: A War variation with 5-card hands by Ed 'Whitey' Walker.

name: 5-2-1 Roll 'Em
notes: A Roll Your Own Poker variant contributed by Arthur Buderick.

name: 7 minus 7
notes: A variation of 7-27 in which red cards have a negative value, by Brian Johnson.

name: 7 Seize
notes: A game by Jeep Barnett in which players play cards from 3-card hands to seize and collect booty. In addition to a standard deck with red and black jokers, the game requires 49 convenient objects of unequal weight to represent booty, a bag to draw them from and a balance to compare the weights of different collections.

name: 10 Bridge
notes: A variation of Bridge, with elements of the Indian game 29, by Basudeo Agarwal.

name: 10 Phases
notes: A Contract Rummy variation inspired by the commercial game Phase 10, contributed by Aaron Barnhart.

name: 21st Century War
notes: A War variation by Osman Hussaini in which the players have some choice of what cards to play.

name: 38's
notes: A Crazy Eights variant by John Ackerman.
A partnership game by Korumiya Kimihiko in which points are won for winning tricks and for cards in the tricks won by the opponents.

name: 92Q
notes: An game of tricks, trumps and bidding, by Chet Leja. As well as a trump suit there is a suit that functions as a duplicate of whatever suit is led. As in some Japanese games, twos are high if everyone follows suit, but low otherwise.

name: 100 Years War
notes: A card game for 2 to 4 players by Alan Smithee. Players collect cards with a view to winning battles decided in favour of the best poker hand.

name: 1000 Blank White Cards
notes: The Discordian Intelligence Agency Edition of a game whose purpose is to create the cards as you play.
A math game for children by Aaron Barnhart in which the aim is to match a four-digit number.
